results.description:
2 Player Games, ANY Game (Previously X-Wing Miniatures)

An opportunity to play those two player games that we do not play on a regular (mostly euro?) boardgaming night.  

If we have an odd number of players, or if we just feel like it, yes, it is fine doing a 3, 4 or 5 player game as well. 

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played? 


Anything.  Bring anything that you think will gather enough interest.  Examples: Netrunner, Marvel Dice Masters, Memoir '44, Twilight Struggle, Few Acres of Snow or even chess if that is your thing.  Put other suggestions on the event comments.

Will try this format a couple of times to see how it goes.

Q.  Should I bring something? 
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served, feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/beverages in the pizza cup.


Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm? 
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it? 
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q. What About X-Wing?
A. If you noticed, this spot is filling up the time previously scheduled for X-Wing Miniatures 100pts - so... as you may have guessed, Randy and I will be setting up a couple of x-wing miniatures tables for those of us inclined towards that game but still want to make the event more inclusive to other game genres (it is not often the wife allows me to invite my friends to play games, so I better make the best use of the time).
results.how_to_find_us: Across from soccer field (that is the alternate parking spot if the driveway fills up).
results.name: 2 Player Games (including X-Wing Miniatures)

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are ladies night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the event Host(s) (see RSVP list) from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from cubbies if available).
results.name: MetroRock Monday

results.description:
Come join us for a lively book discussion -  The Boston Girl  by Anita Diamant


From the New York Times bestselling author of The Red Tent and Day After Night, comes an unforgettable novel about family ties and values, friendship and feminism told through the eyes of a young Jewish woman growing up in Boston in the early twentieth century.


Addie Baum is The Boston Girl, born in 1900 to immigrant parents who were unprepared for and suspicious of America and its effect on their three daughters. Growing up in the North End, then a teeming multicultural neighborhood, Addie’s intelligence and curiosity take her to a world her parents can’t imagine—a world of short skirts, movies, celebrity culture, and new opportunities for women. Addie wants to finish high school and dreams of going to college. She wants a career and to find true love.

Eighty-five-year-old Addie tells the story of her life to her twenty-two-year-old granddaughter, who has asked her “How did you get to be the woman you are today.” She begins in 1915, the year she found her voice and made friends who would help shape the course of her life. From the one-room tenement apartment she shared with her parents and two sisters, to the library group for girls she joins at a neighborhood settlement house, to her first, disastrous love affair, Addie recalls her adventures with compassion for the naïve girl she was and a wicked sense of humor.

Written with the same attention to historical detail and emotional resonance that made Anita Diamant’s previous novels bestsellers, The Boston Girl is a moving portrait of one woman’s complicated life in twentieth century America, and a fascinating look at a generation of women finding their places in a changing world.

We will be choosing a book for October's discssion at this meeting; please come with a book suggestion. We encourage all ages, both men and women.


This event is free, but please support the group and the event location by purchasing a drink or meal while you are at Panera. Please do not bring outside food or drinks into Panera.

results.name: Book Group - The Boston Girl by Anita Diamant

For our June meeting we will continue to discuss Common Core.

Common Core - we are in the thick of it! We will discuss the current and future of the fight, and what we can do. We will talk about the hearings at Bridgewater State University, which hopefully a number of us attended.

Governor Baker has directed Paul Sagan the Massachusetts Board of Education Chair to hold a series of public hearings around the state, which will solicit feedback from educators, parents, students and local officials on the PARCC exam and the real-world impact of Common Core standards on teaching and learning. The dates and locations are as follows. This is our opportunity to let our voices be heard.

The next hearing is Monday, June 22, 2015, North Shore Community College – Lynn Campus, Gymnasium, 4:00–7:00 p.m.

For those not as familiar with Common Core, we will also take some time to watch the presentation of Building The Machine. We will also see a clip or two from the hearings.

If time permits, we will talk about Evan Sayet's to recent Boston appearances. Note he will be returning in the fall.

NOTE: this event is being created by Patrick. Face Book has changed the rules (again) making it impossible to create a FB Public Event for GBTP.

results.description:
In Singing Meditation a simple song is typically sung repetitively by the group until the song spontaneously dissolves into silence with a gentle signal to end the silence after several minutes.

The singing part of “Singing Meditation” includes a variety of vocalizations: toning, chanting, singing in rounds, singing in harmony and mantras. The repertoire is interfaith/non-sectarian: Jewish, Sufi, Native American, Christian, earth-based, Hindu, Buddhist, Pagan and others. Our goal is to sing or chant enough times that our collective vibrations resonate deep in the heart of each participant.
Some of the songs used in Singing Meditation are slow and contemplative. And, some are high energy and joyful with percussion and / or other instruments. The songs in Singing Meditation are deliberately chosen to be easy to learn.

results.description:
Even though the world is full of suffering, new research suggests that we are biologically predisposed to look on the bright side. In her new book 'The Science of Optimism: Why We’re Hard-Wired for Hope', Author Tali Sharot explores the reasons why.

The concept of optimism is often linked with the name of Gottfried Wilhelm Leibniz, who held that we live in the best of all possible worlds, which Voltaire famously mocked in his satirical novel Candide.

Most of us expect outcomes to be better than they are likely to be. We also suffer from what experts call a narcissistic illusion: we are above average, have better luck and have more talented children than others, etc., which cannot possibly be true for everyone.

Although our prediction of the future influences our actions, which in turn determine the outcome, optimism bias also has negative effects: it can cause risky behavior, (the 'it won't happen to ME' syndrome), and poor planning.

Some studies show that mild optimists live longer, but does being healthier make you more positive or does being positive make you healthier? Doesn't worrying about the future allow you to prepare better?

Even entire countries show different levels of optimism. The United States is more optimistic than Europe, even though we have the same culture.

To prepare for this discussion please visit the following links:

The Optimism Bias

Can Positive Thinking be Negative?

The Science of Optimism: A Conversation…

How Full is Your Glass?

What Makes Americans So Optimistic?
results.name: The Optimism Bias: How full is Your Glass?

results.description:
(Please note: many of the friends who attend regularly are not Meetup members, so there are always more people attending that it says on the Meetup site.)

About This Meditation Meetup

We sit in silence for around 45 minutes, followed by discussion for around 30 minutes or so. The silent sitting is interspersed with some meditation instruction, perhaps a brief reading, a little simple inquiry, exploration or movement. Sitting posture is relaxed, either on a meditation cushion or a bench. It's not a rigid practice- move whenever you need to!

We meet every Monday night, 7:30 pm at the Cambridge Friends Meeting House. The Friends Meeting House is located at 5 Longfellow Park, Cambridge, MA 02138 You can find a very good map here: <a href="http://www.fmcquaker.org/FMC-Map_2006.pdf" target="_blank"></a>

http://fmcquaker.org/about-friends-meeting-at-cambridge/directions/

Parking is available after 6:00 in the loop off of Brattle St. that leads to the Friend's House, and there is a small lot in back of the Friend's House for those with limited mobility. After that, parking is a little tricky in Cambridge (lots of "resident only" signs), but you will find available parking on Mount Auburn St. near Friend's House and on Brattle St. as you head away from Harvard Square.

Coming by the T is a great option, with the Friend's House being a lovely 15 minute walk out of Harvard Square.

If you find you are running late, come anyway! The format is very relaxed and open— anyone interested in contemplative practice is welcome!

 

About Open Awareness Meditation Group

At the heart of these meditation sessions is the silent exploration of what we refer to as Open Awareness. We all know what it means to feel closed, limited, vulnerable, or separate. What is it like to allow ourselves to return to our natural condition of openness, presence, non-separateness and ease? This is what we explore in our meetings.

We have been meeting for over a decade, and those who lead the meditations have known each other and been practicing together for many years. They have all deeply explored a variety of traditions— for some it has been the Tibetan Buddhist practices of Dzogchen or Mahamudra, for others it has been the Indian traditions of Yoga, or Advaita, or what is currently referred to as Nonduality (some popular examples of this are Francis Lucille, Rupert Spira, Eckhart Tolle and Adyashanti). 

However all of these traditions ultimately point to the same truth, the truth of our basic awareness or presence which is beyond any tradition, practice or teaching. This is the presence we share, and the presence we are, beyond words. This is what we explore in our meetings.

This group is unique in that there is no specific guiding teacher, lama, or guru. We all meet as equals to question, share, and inspire each other to explore the Open Awareness we most deeply are. The meetings are suitable for newcomers as well as experienced meditators, and all are very welcome.
results.name: Open Awareness Meditation Group Meetup

results.description:
Hello and welcome to another edition of the Manga Club! I hope you are ready for some excitement because this marks the third anniversary of our time together. Thank you all for sticking with me through the good times and the bad :)

Since this is an anniversary meeting, I decided to go big, go strong, and pick a story epic enough to mark this milestone. Therefore, I thought it was time to tackle a classic I’ve been saving for a special occasion. That’s right, quite possibly the best known Shonen title on the planet, Dragon Ball by Akira Toriyama!

That being said, it still did not seem like enough, so I decided to expand my ideas once again, and break from a tradition started from the very first meeting. Yes, I am talking about the ban on the “Big Three” as selectable titles. It was not an easy choice, but given the fact that one of them is already officially over and also features a blonde super powered kid who just keeps getting stronger, Naruto by Masashi Kishimoto made the final cut!

Dragon Ball (3-in-1 Edition), Vol. 1
by Akira Toriyama

A seminal series from a legendary creator. Dragon Ball, a wry update on the Chinese "Monkey King" myth, introduces us to Son Goku, a young monkey-tailed boy whose quiet life is turned upside-down when he meets Bulma, a girl determined to collect the seven "Dragon Balls." If she gathers them all, an incredibly powerful dragon will appear and grant her one wish. But the precious orbs are scattered all over the world, and to get them she needs the help of a certain super-strong boy...

Naruto: 3-in-1 Edition, Vol. 1
by Masashi Kishimoto

Twelve years ago the Village Hidden in the Leaves was attacked by a fearsome threat. A nine-tailed fox spirit claimed the life of the village leader, the Hokage, and many others. Today, the village is at peace and a troublemaking kid named Naruto is struggling to graduate from Ninja Academy. His goal may be to become the next Hokage, but his true destiny will be much more complicated. The adventure begins now!

Copies are available at the venue, and don’t forget our special deal! On the night of the Manga Club, all participants get ten percent off all graphic novels in the store, and twenty five percent off any future Manga Club title releases in stock! So if you come to the June Manga Club event, you can get the July or August titles for twenty five percent off as available!

BUT PLEASE REMEMBER, THIS DISCOUNT ONLY APPLIES TO VOLUMES IN THE STORE ON THE NIGHT OF A MANGA CLUB EVENT! THIS DISCOUNT DOES NOT APPLY AT ANY OTHER TIME OR TO A PREVIOUSLY RESERVED GRAPHIC NOVEL! THIS DEAL IS A GIFT NOT A PRIVILEGE SO PLEASE DO NOT ABUSE IT!

Thank you and I hope to see you there!
results.name: August Manga Club! 3rd Anniversary! Shonen Evolution!

The Westin Waltham Boston
70 3rd Avenue

What is coffee chat?


#CoffeeChat is a time for us to meet while we're on your way to work in the morning or just about to get your day started. We come together for about an hour to share stories and find some common conversation with other people who are working to make positive things happen.


Over the years of attending #CoffeeChat events, we see that people have continued to come together; it's a little bit of networking and a little bit of inspiration. I hope wherever you are you will consider organizing your own morning meetup with like-minded (or different-minded!) people in your community.

When you raise the flag, and let people know what you are interested in (especially if that interest involves bringing like minded people together) you are well on your way to making a positive difference and a significant impact on your local community.

And, if you do schedule a coffee chat, please do let us know; we'll post the event here! I look forward to getting to spend more time with you and the community you surround yourself.

Jason

PS: (the hashtag is how we promote on Instagram, Twitter, etc: #CoffeeChat)

results.description:
Join the NGINX team and fellow users in Boston, MA! We are combining great training along with an afternoon lineup of amazing guest speakers.

For those of you who are newer to NGINX or want to improve your skills, we’ll host our NGINX Fundamentals training on Tuesday morning, August 18. Register here now to receive 50% off training with the code MEETUP.

Our afternoon summit will kick off at 1:30pm with an opening talk by Peter Guagenti, CMO at NGINX. In this session, we'll share strategies to help you move from a monolithic architecture to one that allows you to innovate, respond faster, and give your users the best possible experience. We'll discuss ways to give your users a better experience when failure does happen.

The enlightenment continues with lightning talks from some of the most innovative technologists using NGINX today – Harald Zeitlhofer, Performance Advocate at Dynatrace; Matthew Williams, DevOps Evangelist at Datadog; and David “Chappy” Chlapowski, Regional Manager NYC at Solarflare. 

After all the content, stick around for snacks, drinks, and social time with fellow NGINX users and the NGINX team.

The afternoon summit is entirely free, but it does require pre-registration. Register here for your free Summit Only pass.
results.name: Boston, MA: NGINX Summit + Training

results.description:
Rushdie tix go on sale today at the Harvard Book Store or online (I think). The event itself (RSVP HERE) isn't until September 21st. Details below. 

:: :: ::

Salman Rushdie discusses Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights: A Novel

Co-sponsored by the Nieman Foundation for Journalism

This event includes a book signing. Tickets ($28.75) go on sale August 18th at 9am (book included). 


Monday, September 21, 2015, 7pm (Doors at 6:30)

First Parish Church

1446 Massachusetts Ave., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store and the Nieman Foundation for Journalism are honored to welcome internationally renowned author SALMAN RUSHDIE for a reading from his latest novel, Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights. 

From Salman Rushdie, one of the great writers of our time, comes a spellbinding work of fiction that blends history, mythology, and a timeless love story. A lush, richly layered novel in which our world has been plunged into an age of unreason, Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights is a breathtaking achievement and an enduring testament to the power of storytelling. 

In the near future, after a storm strikes New York City, the strangenesses begin. A down-to-earth gardener finds that his feet no longer touch the ground. A graphic novelist awakens in his bedroom to a mysterious entity that resembles his own sub–Stan Lee creation. Abandoned at the mayor’s office, a baby identifies corruption with her mere presence, marking the guilty with blemishes and boils. A seductive gold digger is soon tapped to combat forces beyond imagining. Unbeknownst to them, they are all descended from the whimsical, capricious, wanton creatures known as the jinn, who live in a world separated from ours by a veil. 

Centuries ago, Dunia, a princess of the jinn, fell in love with a mortal man of reason. Together they produced an astonishing number of children, unaware of their fantastical powers, who spread across generations in the human world. Once the line between worlds is breached on a grand scale, Dunia’s children and others will play a role in an epic war between light and dark spanning a thousand and one nights—or two years, eight months, and twenty-eight nights. It is a time of enormous upheaval, in which beliefs are challenged, words act like poison, silence is a disease, and a noise may contain a hidden curse. 

Inspired by the traditional “wonder tales” of the East, Salman Rushdie’s novel is a masterpiece about the age-old conflicts that remain in today’s world. Two Years Eight Months and Twenty-Eight Nights is satirical and bawdy, full of cunning and folly, rivalries and betrayals, kismet and karma, rapture and redemption. 

Event Co-Sponsor: Nieman Foundation for Journalism: http://nieman.harvard.edu/

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases. 

General Info: (617)[masked] - [masked] 

Media Inquiries: (617)[masked] x1 - [masked] 

Accessibility Inquiries: [masked]
results.name: Rushdie Tix

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Level - Middle intermediates (currently playing volleyball regularly, understands and follows basic rules, able to execute basic pass, set and hit skills, and has good fitness).

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

DIRECTIONS

Carson Beach (limited free parking available), William Day Blvd, South Boston, http://www.bostonharborwalk.com...­

The net is blue. There are 2 parking lots (one on each side of beach house). Park in the southern lot (closer to State Police barracks) (or the one on the right side of the beach house as you look at the ocean). You will be able to see me and the net from there.

Tonight we will be continuing or Xamarin course study.....

Introduction to Xamarin.Forms

This course introduces the basics of developing cross-platform iOS, Android, and Windows Phone applications using Xamarin.Forms. Xamarin.Forms is covered using a very hands-on approach with lots of code and practical examples.

by <a>Jim Wilson</a>

We will Start and try to get through three sections:

Providing UI behaviors with views & XAML

Xamarin Forms ListView

and if we can

Xamarin Forms pages

results.description:
Be it a treasure a classical or new wonder, a mystery, a romance, a chick lit or just a good old fashioned trashy novel.  Let’s meet and talk about them all.  One month we will get serious and read a Treasure; the next month we will read a mystery, a new wonder, a romance, a chick lit or just a good old fashioned trashy novel.

This book club has a little something for everyone. This is a perfect setting for everyone who loves reading and talking books.

This month’s read and discussion is a new wonder:The Light Between Oceans  byM. L. Stedman

No perfumes please we have members with allergies.

Please meet in the backroom after ordering your food

It is a requirement that EVERYONE who attends order food, I can't stress this enough, the restaurant is in business to make $$ and provide a service. We are free to use their party room at no charge if we purchase food. Please respect this request
results.name: Treasure and New Finds Book Club:   The Light Between Oceans  byM. L. Stedman

results.description:
Who wants to get fit for FREE?

Healthy, Fit & Fun promotes exercise and good health in a fun, group setting. People of all ages and abilities are encouraged to come get fit and make new friends while enjoying the beauty of the Esplanade. The Esplanade Association partners with organizations around Boston to offer a diverse array of expert-led fitness classes. All classes are free and open to the public. Registration is required to participate you may pre- register at the event.


Fusing Latin rhythms and easy to follow moves, nothing is more fun and healthy than a high energy Zumba workout. Routines feature interval training sessions where fast and slow rhythms are combined with resistance training. Come get your groove on and break a sweat on the Esplanade. Classes begin 7/14 Classes sponsored by Healthworks. Refreshments provided by Zico and CLIF.

By pre-registering you will receive email updates with any class changes or cancellations.

Help to support their free public programming - make a donation.

results.description: Drop by anytime between 6:00 and 8:30 PM to have a drink, share some apps, and say hello to fellow waterskiiers! We'll be coordinating upcoming waterski meetups so that we can all get out on the water soon.
results.name: Waterski Meet & Greet

results.description:
Wayne J. has organized this event.

 Come and enjoy the cool summer breezes coming off the waters of Boston Harbor while viewing one of the most  breathtakingly spectacular views of the Boston skyline.  Located on the very edge of the shoreline with access to the water for cooling your feet in the refreshing water.

If you prefer not to take advantage of the four hours of free automobile parking at the Hyatt you can take the Water Taxi Shuttle from Long Wharf to the Airport stop abutting the Hyatt Hotel. If you drive get your parking ticket validated at the Bell Captains station inside the main entrance

Having arrived, enter the Harborside Lounge on the ground floor to your right of the Main front entrance and join your Sitz friends and those prospective members who want to know more about the good things they’ve heard about Sitz and their interesting members.

Enjoy complimentary light hors d’oeuvres provided by Sitz members. Beverages are  available for purchase at the Bar.

Feel free to arrive early or stay late for fine dining in the luxurious and comfortable Harborside Grill and Patio. The culinary staff at one of the best restaurants in Boston prepares outstanding Bistro and New England Specialities created with organic and sustainable ingredients from local farmers.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in the Harborside Grill
results.name: A Harborside Afterwork

results.description:
Due to popular demand/requests, I've decided to schedule another evening at the Clayroom. This place was a lot of fun last time we went. As you know Tuesdays are free pizza night and you can bring your own beer/drinks.

Accessible via Public Transportation. Off the Green Line - C. You can get off at Coolidge Corner or Summit Ave.
results.name: Pottery / Painting @ The Clayroom

results.description:
Public speaking with ease and impact in front of any group.

Imagine standing in front of any audience, feeling absolutely confident and at ease.

Whether you have public speaking anxiety or simply want to express yourself with greater clarity the experience in a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity

Speaking Circles help:

Business professionals become more effective, authentic and powerful. 

People expand their vision of what life could be like when they are able to

be fully present, confident and authentic. 

People who suffer from stage fright to overcome their fears.

Hope to see you soon,

Dexter Nardella

At a Speaking Circle you are provided all the support you need to express yourself in your own time and in your own unique way, without fear or discomfort. Some call this depth of expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.” Whatever you call it, you know when you are there; you know when someone else is there.  Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle.  

http://www.speakingcirclesinternational.com/Articles/Principles/FAQ.html#.VKx9y0c76rU

See and hear participants talk about their experience in SPEAKING CIRCLES: http://youtu.be/Wi82ZIgioh0
results.name: From Anxiety To Authentic Presence

results.description:
Brian Cardarella will be speaking about iex, the interactive Elixir console.

Matthew Ahrens is going to speak about BlockyTalky.

Pizza / Soda will be provided by our firends at Localytics
results.name: August 2015 Meetup

results.description:
We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.
results.name: Quite Write: Writing Night!

venue.name: Harvard TH Chan School of Public Health

results.description:
https://www.google.com/maps/dir/ - for Google Maps

Directions from YOUR starting point...

Until further notice, we're in Kresge 201 (which has been newly-refurbished), at the top of the open stairwell near the guard's desk near the Countway Courtyard entrance to the Kresge Building.

Fred (ZHOU Hanlin) and Justin Kwan host these friendly meetups (in Kresge 201).  
Enter as you have long done; then walk UP the open stairway near the security guard's desk.

* Mandarin speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?
* English speakers want to learn Mandarin?
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Mandarin?

Schedule:
Before 6:30 pm - free conversations - so arrive early - as early as 5:30 pm

[masked] Introductions! A great chance to get to know each other.
[masked] Presentation in two languages
[masked] ...
[masked] Continue playing and free chat.
9.00 Dinner.

时间表：

[masked] 自我介绍

[masked]

[masked]

[masked] 自由交流和游戏

9.00 有兴趣的可以去吃晚餐

Our location this week is Kresge 201 (remodeled classroom) in the most gracious and globally conscious Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, where health-conscious and energy-conscious building and curriculum modifications have been made.

Until further notice, we're in Kresge 201, at the top of the open stairwell near the guard's desk near the Countway Courtyard entrance to the Kresge Building.

All attendees need to register IN ADVANCE to get an HSPH building permission for the night.

E-Mail [masked] to register your intent AND sign YES on this meetup.

下午6点到晚上8点3

PLEASE (try to) request by 4 pm the day before the Tuesday evening event.

* Harvard Square to LMA is about 30 minutes on #66 bus or M2 Harvard bus
* Green Line E-Line comes to Brigham Circle, then walk BACK to crosswalk, then to the building
* Walking from the Orange Line takes about 5-10 minutes, via Tremont Street to Brigham Circle
* Walking from Brookline is about 10 minutes - via Huntington Avenue or Longwood Avenue
* MFA, NEU, Wentworth, and Colleges of the Fenway are adjacent - on or off Huntington Avenue
* Route 9 comes right into the area, via Brookline - passes Huntington Avenue D-line stop
* Street parking is FREE from 6 pm onward (but not always easy to find)

Show your CURRENT LOCAL ID to the HSPH Security Guard on duty, then walk up the open indoor stairwell near the Kresge security guard, then straight up the stairwell, then turn left to Kresge 201 (follow signs to Kresge 201).

E-Mail [masked]
for a building pass if you don't have a Harvard ID; we convene in Kresge 201;
you may wish to ask the HSPH security guard how to access Kresge 201

PLEASE plan to show up early so we can begin our 'bilingual introductions' on time, so our presenter can begin (and end) on time.
results.how_to_find_us: Show your CURRENT LOCAL ID to the HSPH Security Guard, then go UP the OPEN stairwell (follow signs to Kresge 201, IN THE CORNER)
results.name: Mandarin Club Bilingual Chat in Harvard's Longwood Medical Area 下午6点到晚上8点

group.name: The Boston China Interest Network 波士顿中国兴趣俱乐部

results.description:
Join us for the monthly meeting of CTO School in Boston.

6:30-7:00 - mingling with other members, dinner 
7:00-8:00 - speakers 
8:00-8:30ish - more mingling

Please share with other engineering leaders who would enjoy learning from and connecting with peers.

Speaker

Richard Kasperowski - Culture for Great Teams and Results

Your team can be ten times better. What does that mean? That means your professional team can accomplish 10x more work, do it with 10x more quality, 10x faster, or with 10x less resources. Your family can be 10x happier. Your school can be 10x more effective at helping people learn. Your community group can be 10x better at making life better for the people it serves. Even you yourself can be 10x more effective at getting what you want. In other words, you can be great. Your team can be great.

Richard Kasperowski a signatory of the Manifesto for Greatness and cofounder of the Greatness Guild. He works as an Agile trainer and coach, Open Space facilitator, Core Protocols trainer and coach, and he volunteers as a CoderDojo mentor. Richard is the author of The Core Protocols: A Guide to Greatness. Follow him on Twitter at @rkasper, read more about him at www.kasperowski.com, and email him at [masked].

<a href="http://jeremydeane.net"></a>
results.name: August 2015 Monthly Meetup

results.description:
Let's try Kitty Whist.  This will be new for the group so I hope some experienced people show up t help the Newbies play this fun game.

There is always conversation and dinner first but then we can split up and play a few tables of Kitty Whist.

Whether you prefer board games, card games or party games (or just want to meet people!), Tuesday nights will be your opportunity! We welcome new additions to the group, and it's great to see new friendships being made over board games and cards...

Although we start around 6:30pm or so, early birds can take advantage of their half-price happy hour menu. These are full-portion sized appetizers for real cheap! If not, you'll still be able to take advantage of the monthly specials

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that C&C members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Play/Learn Kitty Whist

results.description:
Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

results.description:
General Assembly and The UX Awards present a workshop about Top Trends in Award-Winning UX in Boston on August 18th instructed by UX Awards Executive Director, Beverly May, and special guest, Alec Francesconi, president of Cantina.

When: Tuesday, 18 August, 6:30 – 8:45 pm EDT

Where: GA Boston: 51 Melcher Street, Boston , MA 02210

Register at General Assembly for free.

About This Event

What are the trends and common traits behind the winners at the UX Awards, and where are they headed?

Beverly May, Executive Director of the UX Awards, will present an overview of the UXies, showcase past winning work and case studies, and provide a quantitative and qualitative analysis of winning submissions and UX trends from the past four years that you can use to help improve your own portfolios, UX presentations, or awards submissions.

Beverly will be joined by past winners and supporters of the UX Awards – including special guest Alec Francesconi, President of Cantina a Boston-based digital design and development agency to talk about what they prioritize to make great UX, what great UX is and how you can represent that in a case study, how they approached crafting their own case studies. This event is in partnership with General Assembly, a global partner of the UX Awards 2015.

Agenda Overview of UX Awards

UX Awards: Top Trends in Award Winning UX

What Makes a Winning UX Case Study

Standout Examples of Winning Submissions from 2014 with Alec Francesconi, President of Cantina

Q&A With Guest Speakers, Judges and Winners

Refreshments & Networking

Beverly May Founder and Executive Director,
The UX Awards

Beverly is the founder and Executive Director of the UXies. She has nearly 2 decades` experience in tech, product development and UX and has helped launch hundreds of new digital initiatives at digital agencies, tech incubators, startups, major publishers and in Peacekeeping at the UN. Beverly is currently CTO & Head of Product and UX at a Castaclip, a 35-person mobile video software company in Berlin, Germany. Prior to that, she most recently taught UX at General Assembly and founded and led Oxford Tech, a boutique UX and product strategy consultancy in NY and San Francisco for the past 6 years that specialized in digital publishing and media. Beverly has an Executive MBA from the University of Oxford, a Master`s degree from NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program, and a BA from University of Toronto. She is a triple UK- Canadian- US citizen. She is also a regular public speaker and mentor on UX for incubators, startups and at UX events.Linkedin.com/in/BeverlyMay


Alec Francesconi President,
Cantina

Alec is President of Cantina, a Boston-based digital design and development agency. Since 2007, Cantina has helped entrepreneurs and enterprise clients shape, design, and build successful digital products. Our approach, which combines the best in design and technical architecture with full stack development, offers clients an independent innovation delivery partner.

Alec holds a BA from McGill University in Political Science and History and a diploma in Audio Production from the Center of Digital Imaging Arts at Boston University and is active as a musician and producer with film and music engineering credits to his name.

About Our Partners UX Awards

The UXies are the premier global awards for UX. Now in their 5th year, the UXies inspire all technologists to create human-centered products that solve real customer problems based on exceptional case study showcases of outstanding digital product design and user centered design process. The UXies honor the people, products, best practices and amazing outcomes of great UX process!

The UXies are accepting submissions NOW through September 15, 2015 for the 2015 Awards, which will be held November 16, 2015 in New York! Come to the event to learn more about submitting, or visit UXAwards.org for more info.

Refund Policy Plans change. We get it. But if you can’t make it to a class/workshop, please email us at least 7 days before the scheduled event date. No refunds will be given after this timeframe.
Register for free at General Assembly.

Follow us on Twitter and tweet @OxfordTech & @UXAwards or connect with us on Facebook for news about upcoming UX Events.
results.name: UX Awards: Top Trends in Award-Winning UX Boston

results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog

results.description:
Valerie Hammond will be leading this meditation.

The Seated Awareness Meditation includes breath awareness, body awareness, sound awareness, thought awareness, and choiceless (open) awareness. In partnership with the Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages store, MindfulBoston teachers and teacher-trainees will be leading a series of Meditation events in the coming months as a service to our community.

Place:
The Cambridge Ten Thousand Villages is located at
694 Massachusetts Avenue
Central Square, Cambridge 02139
Time:
6:45pm to 8pm

Schedule:
There will be an informal schedule.
At about 6:45pm we'll set up some seats and have a chat about what meditation is about. This is the official start time for our event.

The front door will be locked by 7:01. Make sure to arrive either on-time or early!
The store's registers will be closed by 7:05 so that employees can join us in meditation.

How to reserve your space:

Please rsvp here or call the store to rsvp. There are no "tickets" but we would like a head count in order to prepare a big enough space for sitting together.

Note: we typically have up to 30 people attend these events. RSVPing is pretty important because we need to move bookcases around to fit everybody in the space. Thanks! 

Seating:
If you have hip/knee or other reasons to need a chair, make sure to rsvp here and say 'reserve a chair' in your comments.
There are seven folding chairs and a few low stools. Zafu style cushions are sometimes available if the store has some in stock. But there are no guarantees. Most of us will be sitting on the floor. Feel free to bring your own pillow with you. What is planned:
The hour (or so) that we spend together will include: discussion about awareness and mindfulness meditation, and an experience of seated awareness meditation. The length of the meditation itself will probably be about 15 to 20 minutes long. No previous experience is required, the meditation will be easy for beginners to understand.

results.description:
This Reiki Share is for you if you have been attuned as a Reiki Practitioner it is a powerful group Reiki session for all level Reiki Practitioners. A safe, supportive, nurturing and positive space is created for us to develop, practice and give back Reiki with like-minded friends. It is a great time to give yourself a tune-up and relish in Reiki.  Each practitioner will have the opportunity to give and receive Reiki during this relaxation and rejuvenating Reiki Share. Contact me if you have questions.

  Reiki Share Agenda

• The 1st 15 minutes of each share we will have time to connect with friends and introduce new members, allowing time to center and prepare for our Reiki sessions.

• It is our goal that each practitioner will have the opportunity to relish in 20 to 30 minutes of Reiki; dependent on how many practitioners are present for the share. 

• We will make every effort to synchronize each session allowing for the highest healing good of each person.

• Quiet discussion of the sessions may be shared quietly while your group is preparing for the next person.

• The room will be available at the conclusion of the Reiki Share so that you can socialize, give feedback and network with like-minded friends.

  Reiki Share Guidelines

• RSVP so that we may plan for adequate space and tables.

• Arrive on time, this allows time to center and enjoy the evening in a stress free manner.

• Please silence or turn off cell/mobile phones.

• During the share please be respectful of other groups enjoying Reiki by keeping conversations to a whisper and as brief as possible.  There will be ample time at the end of the evening for comments and discussions.

• If arriving late to the share, please enter the room "quietly" so the active session is not disturbed.  You may spend time in quite mediation, preparing for Reiki or enjoying self Reiki joining a group when the monument presents itself.  

Donations will be collected to offset the cost of the room.

results.description:
Though we might wish we could, we can't always think of everything ourselves. Join Danny and other writers for a chance to engage your writing with a community and get the kind of new, original feedback that gets the writing juices flowing. Before every meeting we'll each submit a short story, section of a novel or other work to be reviewed (up to 10-12 double spaced pages or[masked] words*). Come prepared to give written and verbal feedback on others' work as well as receive feedback on your own. Open to all, but limited to 5 each session (plus organizers) on a first come first serve basis.

Please RSVP and be prepared to submit your work about a week before we meet to give everyone a chance to read. The latest time to RSVP is 3 days prior.

Submissions are hosted on a shared Box.com folder, which requires an email address to access.  If this is your first time joining, let Danny know your preferred email address and he will invite you.

Monthly
Cost is $15

Led by Danny Shain

Danny graduated from Union College with a degree in English, and has spent years working as a copy-editor, freelance writer and blogger.  A follower of technology trends whose reading interests range from the fantastical to the contemporary to the philosophical, Danny is excited to help people refine their writing, express themselves, and build a writing community through this workshop.

*Note: If you'd like to include slightly more than 10-12 pages to provide some context (ie: your chapter ends 1-2 pages later) that's ok, but please indicate which pages you'd like critiqued. Pages beyond that should be submitted as an optional read.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask the concierge when you come in and you will be directed to the conference room.
results.name: The Writer's Table Critique Sessions

results.description:
This Meetup is intended for intermediate level players or higher, which means:Yankee C and above level, players with firm understanding of game strategy. Should be able to play 5-1 and 6-2 formations, have a good grasp of skills (passing, setting, hitting) and be able to move around to cover areas of the court. Play should consistently be bump-set-spike.



If you'd like to play, please do the following:


1. Send an email to Kory using the following URL: http://www.meetup.com/volleyball-122/message/?recipientId=8675200

2. In the message please indicate the date of event and your preferred position so we can make sure we have the right mix. ( If I don't know your position already)

Note that sending an email does not guarantee a spot to play; spots are only guaranteed if you receive a positive confirmation email. We will do our best to make sure the event is co-ed, have setters,  and incorporate a couple new members who want to join as well.

The location for this volleyball meetup is at the Orient Heights Community Center located at 86 Boardman Street in East Boston. Kory and Wing will be hosting these Tuesday night volleyball meetups.

This event is free if you are a member of Boston Community Centers. If not, it's a one-time $20 membership fee that is valid for a year. The Community Center is a short walk away from the Orient Heights T Stop on the Blue Line and also has plenty of parking. When you drive up, turn at the Mariott Hotel Sign and park in the lot or further along the fence.

As always, please remember:

- Respect the RSVP system (Don't show up expecting to play without a confirmed RSVP)

- The gym is open before the event to warm up, so please arrive a little early if you would like to warm up and stretch as we would like to start the game promptly from 7:00PM

- If it looks like you won't be able to make it or will run late please cancel your RSVP in time for someone else to join.  Event day/last minute cancellations and no shows will jeopardize your participation in future events.
results.name: 8/18 Intermediate+ Indoor Volleyball East Boston

results.description:
Delicious Rot: Using Fermented Foods to Unlock Secrets of the Microbial World featuring Tuft's Benjamin Wolf


Humans have been using microbes to make fermented foods such as cheese, miso, and beer for thousands of years.  Benjamin Wolfe, Asst. Professor of Microbiology at Tufts University, will discuss how these traditional foods are now serving a new purpose - as model ecosystems for microbiologists. From microbial war and peace on Camembert to the funk in your homemade kimchi, learn how some of your favorite foods are changing our understanding of the microbial world.

Benjamin Wolfe is an Assistant Professor of Microbiology in the Department of Biology at Tufts University. His lab uses food microbial communities to address fundamental questions in microbial ecology and evolution. He received his B.Sc. from Cornell University in 2003 and his Ph.D. from Harvard University in 2010. He developed an interest in food microbial communities as a post-doc with Rachel Dutton at Harvard's FAS Center for Systems Biology.  Benjamin is a passionate promoter of microbial literacy through teaching and writing. He has taught food microbiology courses at the Harvard Summer School and Boston University's Gastronomy Program and has taught classes or workshops at Formaggio Kitchen, the San Francisco Cheese School, and for artisan food guilds across the country. Benjamin is a regular contributor to the food magazine Lucky Peach and writes an online series about the biology of food for Boston magazine. He is a co-founder of MicrobialFoods.org, a website that digests the science of fermented foods.




This is a free event, but limited seating is available.


We encourage you to you RSVP through Eventbrite:

http://www.eventbrite.com/e/delicious-rot-using-fermented-foods-to-unlock-secrets-of-the-microbial-world-with-benjamin-wolfe-tickets-18044608911

Directions to Le Laboratoire Cambridge, 650 East Kendall Street Public Transit: Red line to Kendall Square, walk straight down 3rd Street, turn right onto Athenaeum Street, and left onto East Kendall Parking: There is a parking deck - the 650 East Kendall Street Garage - accessible by Linskey Way.


If you purchase food or drink from Le Lab, your parking ticket can be validated for discounted rates.
results.name: CafeSci Boston - “Delicious Rot: Using Fermented Foods..."

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email. 

(Technical Support:[masked]) 


Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

This free session will be facilitated by a trained Isha Kriya instructor. Contact: [masked],[masked] for more information about Isha USA or this session.

For more on Sadhguru and Isha, visit IshaUSA.org/blog
results.name: Isha Kriya Guided Meditation--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
Requirements:

• Must be a Massachusetts licensed real estate agent to attend.
• Seating is limited to the first 15 registrations


Most real estate agents have 2 revenue streams: 

1. Working with buyers to purchase a home for them to live in and

2. Working with sellers by listing and their home. 

Learn how to add additional revenue streams to your real estate business by attending this lunch and learn event hosted by Tom Cafarella of Ocean City Development. The presentation will focus on adding additional revenue streams to your real estate brokerage business including:


1. Making money by helping us acquire properties: Think it would be easier to approach an expired listing or FSBO with an offer in hand from a cash buyer?  We'll show you how to easily get in front of more sellers.
2. Our Automated Short Sale System:  Learn how to capitalize on short sales while keeping your sanity.  Our automated short sale program allows agents to spend a very limited amount of time and effort while maximizing their commissions.
3. Buyer Lead Overflow: we don't work with buyers, but that doesn't mean you shouldn't.  Learn how working with an investor can provide you with an overflow of buyer leads and how we generate these leads(mostly by accident).
4. Learn how to make money by wholesaling properties & raising capital: we'll show you how to easily and effectively add these two revenue streams to your real estate business.

As an added bonus, we will be reviewing our best practices and systems to allow you to leverage your time and efforts in 2015.  

Tom is a principle of Ocean City Development and is head of acquisitions. Tom has been on the front lines of Ocean City Development's team, and has acquired over 62 properties to fix and flip over the past 12 months. Environment & Structure of Event: The presentation will be held in our conference room in Wakefield and we will be providing lunch and refreshments. Seating is limited to the first 15 registrants and the presentation will be followed by a Question and Answer session. The presentation and Question and answer will end at approximately 12pm and for those who want to stick around or have additional 1 on 1 questions we will be ending at 12:30pm.
results.name: Making Money w/Ocean City - Lunch & Learn - Creating  Additional Revenue Streams

In order to play we need to know if we have enough players.  So, if you are planning on coming, it is important that you RSVP otherwise we'll have to cancel.

I'll send out a confirmation Wednesday afternoon to let you know whether the game is on.

Remember to bring a white and dark shirt (no grey) as well as your soccer gear to work in case we play.

Thanks,

-Dave

results.description:
Boston Computational Biology & Bioinformatics is pleased to present another BCBB networking night brought to you by our first repeat sponsor, the International Society for Computational Biology! We had an amazing 100+ member night back in June, and after a bit of a summer break we're looking forward to getting back into the swing of things. We'll be back in our familiar space in the upstairs area at Meadhall starting at 5:30 on August 19th. 


The ISCB will be sponsoring a selection of pub food. Come and share comp bio tales of triumph and woe with your peers over the Meadhall's excellent selection of beers and complementary hand cut chips, chicken wings, veggie plates, and hummus platters.


Invest in you, your research field - Become an ISCB Member Today!

International Society for Computational Biology (ISCB) has emerged as the leading professional society for participants in the field of computational biology and bioinformatics. This diverse group of nearly 3,400 global members includes researchers, practitioners, technicians, students, and suppliers. ISCB Members find their experience and our benefits far exceed the investment. Click here to go to the registration page and start or renew your membership today: http://www.iscb.org/become-a-member

**** UPDATE *****

Due to event size, Syros Pharmaceuticals, our second repeat sponsor, has stepped in to increase the food budget. Thanks, Syros!

Syros is a young, well-funded biotech startup utilizing computational biology & (epi-)genomics for drug discovery, and they are preparing to grow their computational biology & bioinformatics team. Keep an eye on http://www.syros.com/careers for future openings.

results.description:
Hi All!
A number of you have shown interest in a weekday evening meetup in the downtown Boston area. Here it is! Please come and join us for a casual 2 hours ASL social on Wednesdays from 5:30 to 7:30 pm.


WHO: All who are interested in ASL are welcome to join us. Whether you're Deaf or hearing, beginner or fluent ASL user, we're here to share and socialize in this beautiful language.

WHERE: We'll be in the City Place Food Court in Dept of Transportation Building (use entrance on Boylston Street across street from Boylston Street T stop or entrance on Stuart Street) . Since we'll most likely be the only group of people signing, we should be pretty easy to spot.

RULES: Voices off, use paper and pen if you need to--this helps us learn and its Deaf friendly


RESOURCES: For those of you who are new to ASL and want to come prepared, here are some very good websites with free online classes.

http://www.westwoodasl.com/ http://www.lifeprint.com/ http://www.start-american-sign-language.com/

RSVP: Please RSVP for the meetup that you will be attending so we know how many people to expect.

CONTACT: Please feel free to contact host (Sean) if you have any questions or concerns. Hope to see you there! :)

results.description:
Yours Sincerely, John S. Sargent

John Singer Sargent comes to life through letters and lore

Behind the renowned paintings of John Singer Sargent lies another legacy—a treasure trove of letters, photographs, and sketches that document the artist’s world. Among the correspondence, more than a dozen letters from Sargent to Claude Monet illuminate his lifelong friendship and admiration for the French Impressionist master. Another note, carefully written in a neat round hand, describes a certain portrait as a “masterpiece”; it is signed Amélie Gautreau, an appreciative sitter best known today as Madame X. 

In celebration of the recent gift to the MFA of The John Singer Sargent Archive, which establishes the Museum as the center for Sargent scholarship, this exhibition selected from the archive and the MFA’s collection, brings Sargent’s era to life, enhancing our understanding of the man and his work. The show features  watercolors, prints,drawings, correspondence, and photographs arranged around several themes. Caricatures of Sargent by his friends and fellow artists Henry Tonks and Max Beerbohm add a dose of humor to our view of this hard-working artist, while sketches, props, and photographs of his studios illuminate his artistry and reveal the spaces of his labor.


Gonzalo Fuenmayor: Tropical Mythologies


SMFA graduate Gonzalo Fuenmayor explores notions of national identity, geographic displacement, and colonial histories in his first solo exhibition at the MFA.

Fuenmayor’s Colombian heritage and Latino identity collide in works that address Latin America’s colonial past and its legacy. With an elegant flourish, he collages familiar symbols of Latin America with those of Europe, melding bananas and jungle foliage with ornate decorative objects and opulent architecture. His unexpected combinations harness the complex culture clash and enduring tension between the two regions. They also reference “magical realism”—the literary genre marked by a blend of the fantastic and mundane, perhaps best known today through the works of fellow Colombian Gabriel García Márquez and Argentina’s Jorge Luis Borges.

Fuenmayor earned his Master of Fine Arts degree at the School of the Museum of Fine Arts in 2004. In 2013, he was awarded the School’s prestigious Traveling Fellowship. He used the funds to visit part of his native country that he had never seen before: Leticia, Colombia’s southern-most city, which sits on the banks of the Amazon River where Colombia, Brazil, and Peru converge. This inspired Fuenmayor to make work on a Colombian banana plantation; his first video art piece, on view in the exhibition, documents that experience.
results.name: MFA - Free Wednesday - Art of John Singer Sargent and Gonzalo Fuenmayor

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.
results.how_to_find_us: We meet on the grassy patch between the Children's Museum & the Barking Crab Restaurant

At the fused glass art classes at Glass, Arts and More you will create your own glass masterpiece from an 8 x 8 sq. in. sheet of fusible glass. During this two-to -three-hour-long class you will learn how to cut glass, design your pieces, and the basics of fusing glass in the kiln.  The pieces you create will have to fire overnight and could take up to a week to be ready, depending on the number of students in the classroom and the number of kilns available.  You will be able to come back to collect the pieces once the firing and cooling process has completed.  

Course Fee: $40 per participant.

results.description:
Join our August Bluemix meet up for a DevOps night.  


IBM® Bluemix™ DevOps Services is software as a service (SaaS) on the cloud that supports continuous delivery. With DevOps Services, you can develop, track, plan, and deploy software in one place. From your projects, you can access everything that you need to build all kinds of apps. You can work on your own or use the collaboration tools to work with a team. After you build an app, you can deploy it to the IBM® Bluemix™ cloud platform. In minutes, you can go from source code to a running app.At our meet up, we will:


Discuss the theory of DevOps services and what it actually brings to the table See a live demo of the Bluemix DevOps services capabilities in an IBM Watson related appLearn what DevOps services offers to developers


Presented by: 

Priya Aswani, MSCS, Lean Six Sigma IBM Cloud

Bluemix Growth Hacking Dev Mgr

@BluemixDevOps 


Resource link: https://hub.jazz.net/

Still haven't registered for your free Bluemix account?   Sign up here to get started:  www.ibm.biz/cloudboston
results.name: August Bluemix Meetup: DevOps

results.description:
Networking


The Beacon Business Club is a distinct type of networking group. The best business is done with people who have integrity, are kind and create win-win situations for everyone involved. The BBC is committed to celebrating these people in our area and connecting them to each other with a strong emphasis on referrals. Join us!

Knowledge

Social Networking is great, but we are aiming higher. At every BBC event, we add value by sharing cutting-edge knowledge aimed to benefit small and mid sized businesses. You come to our events or seminars knowing your passion and leave with new ideas, actionable tasks and visual assets to share your passion successfully.

Service

In addition to meeting people and learning at our events, BBC also offers services at deeply discounted prices, such as headshots. Photos are powerful - people often make decisions based on how you look! Make sure you have a professionally taken photo that respresents you at your best! For only $59 you receive a makeup touch-up, and a high resolution image for your professional or personal use! Photos are taken in portrait studio either at event or on follow-up date. 

Networking: Elevate your Elevator Pitch
Knowledge: Referral Best Practices 
Service: Professional Headshot

$15 entry fee includes finger foods, drinks and attendee contact list
Optional headshot $59 includes makeup touch-up and a high resolution image

results.description:
Mindfulness is a way of focusing on the sensations and breath/lifeforce that we often ignore leading us to experience stress (anxiety) in a negative way.  This is why movement and mindfulness reduces those responses in your body and you feel relaxed.

Every body needs to exercise with mindfulness which is something everyone needs to do just as much as preventative maintenance on your car is necessary. 

Learn new stress reduction techniques that can help you reserve your energy and harness the power within you, sleep better and more.

It is best to prepay $90 for 6 wks to assure your spot & motivate you. Suggested Donation is $20 walk-ins must make an appointment/RSVP ~ ask about a sliding scale

Reserve your spot asap and cancel ASAP if you have signed up and can not come. Class sized are limited due to space limitation.
