results.description:
"The camera is an instrument that teaches people how to see without a camera."Dorothea Lange

This Saturday afternoon I am combining my two favorite topics in one special photo opportunity: Mindfulness and Macro Photography. Get ready to go slow, see deeply and experience a shift in how you perceive the beauty of life. I am opening my art studio at the the Boston Center for the Arts just for you so you can discover how to take better macro photos.

This is a rain or shine event. We will work inside my studio building and if weather permits we will have an exercise out in the South End. 

If you have a macro lens, this is the perfect time to break it out and really learn how to use it to full advantage. If you don't have a macro lens fear not! You can use the close up/flower setting on your camera. 

Before you can really connect, you need to shift into a more contemplative mindset. I will guide you through some simple mindfulness exercises you can use anytime any where to help you slow down and be more present. These simple techniques will immediately open your eyes to more subtle qualities of color, light, texture and shape that usually go unnoticed. Macro requires patience and deep seeing. 

Bokeh Technique: Japanese aesthetic of blurring the background so your subject captivates our attention and appreciation. This will be one of the techniques I will introduce during the workshop.

What you will learn during this workshop:

• How to enter the "flow" state using mindful breathing techniques to be patient and slow down.

• What camera settings are best for macro photography

• How to create the Bokeh effect and blur the background

• How to make sure your subject is in sharp focus

• How to use CREATIVE COMPOSITION for added impact

• How to shoot nature and man made object using available light


 (I will bring flowers for the shoot.)

You will also receive lesson cards summarizing the content of the class and assignments so you can practice again on your own after the workshop. And I will provide individual guidance and feedback both during and after the class. 


Tuition for this three hour workshop is $30. 

I am limiting this class to 12 participants so please RSVP now if you would like a space. I am really looking forward to offering this workshop. After class we will go next door to the Beehive for refreshments if you would like to join us for the social time.

Once you signup you will receive a more detailed email from me about what to bring, what to wear, and how to prepare. We are going to have a great time so I hope you will join us for this go slow, photo workshop! All levels are welcome and any camera will work just fine as long as it has a close up setting.


Join us for this relaxing, inspiring experience. You will meet great people and discover how to take better pictures. All you need to do is RSVP now.

See you Saturday at 3:00 pm. You have joined the group, now join the fun!

Suzanne

Sneak Peek: My studio beautiful at the Boston Center for the Arts. Packed with fascinating object to photograph. All for you! 

http://itunes.apple.com/us/book/flow-tography-better-photos/id499049037?mt=11&uo=4  Click here to see more details about my book if you have an iPad.

results.description:
Our good friend, Bob Faw, is hosting a fun day at his pond side home in Hudson, NH. Come join us for the fun, food, and the feature film about the world-famous magician, escape artist, and world-renowned enemy of deception, James "The Amazing" Randi. 

This is a potluck event! Items brought should somewhat reflect the amount of people going. Please list what you're going to contribute. 

If you'd rather donate to the event instead of participating in the potluck. We are suggesting $20 towards food and preparations for this event per person.

Come early to enjoy the following: 
(note: pictures below are not visible in mobile app for some reason)

4pm - FUN 
swimming/outdoor stuff/relax & enjoy the fauna and flora

Kick-off your shoes and get your toes in the sand and water. (picture)

Chill out by the dock. (picture) 

Bask in the majestic nature of the pond. (picture) 


... and witness the amazing rock hunting and stick retrieving prowess of Neesha the wonder dog! (picture) 


6pm - FEAST 
bbq/potluck on the pond (picture)

7:30pm - FEATURE
watch the film (picture)

See the film trailer here. http://anhonestliar.com/wp/trailer/


From the website: 
"The film brings to life Randi’s intricate investigations that publicly exposed psychics, faith healers, and con-artists with quasi-religious fervor. A master deceiver who came out of the closet at the age of 81, Randi created fictional characters, fake psychics, and even turned his partner of 25 years, the artist Jose Alvarez, into a sham guru named Carlos. But when a shocking revelation in Randi’s personal life is discovered, it isn’t clear whether Randi is still the deceiver – or the deceived."

We are going to have a great time! Please come and join us for this fun summer-time event.
results.name: "An Honest Liar" documentary with food and fun

results.description:
The shifting Warp Storms that surround the long lost Herakon Cluster have finally abated, leaving the ancient treasures and planets within this sector open to the rest of the galaxy. Now, the great factions of the galaxy mobilize their fleets and race to establish a foothold. The reward for successful domination surpasses all other concerns, and the price for conquering this sector will be paid in lives.

Forbidden Stars challenges you and up to three other players to take command of a mighty fighting force: the Ultramarines chapter of Space Marines, the Eldar of Craftworld Iyanden, the Evil Sunz Ork clan, or the World Eaters Warband of the Chaos Space Marines. Each faction offers unique armies and play styles, but your goal remains the same – to claim the key objectives selected for your faction. These objective tokens are scattered throughout the Herakon Cluster, but your opponents are sure to defend your objectives against you. You need to build massive armies and command them in unending war to best your enemies and claim your objectives. The fight for the Herakon Cluster is brutal and bloody, and you will either stride triumphant over the bodies of your fallen foes, or they will do the same to you.

If you are new to the game and want an overview of it to make teaching go smoother I have linked the Miami Dice review below. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aZBrPHjtB-c

Hope to start shortly after my game of Civilisations is complete.
results.name: Forbidden Stars at the All-Day Quarterly

results.description:
PHOENIX ADVANCED TICKETS


A spellbinding mystery of identity, illusion and deception unfolds against the turmoil of post-World War II Germany in the stunning new film from acclaimed writer/director Christian Petzold (Barbara, Jerichow). Berlin, 1945: Nelly (Nina Hoss, A Most Wanted Man), a German-Jewish, ex-nightclub singer, has survived a concentration camp. But, like her country, she is scarred, her face disfigured by a bullet wound. After undergoing reconstructive surgery, Nelly emerges with a new face, one similar but different enough that her former husband, Johnny (Ronald Zehrfeld), doesn’t recognize her. Rather than reveal herself, Nelly walks into a dangerous game of duplicity and disguise as she tries to figure out if the man she loves may have been the one who betrayed her to the Nazis. Submerged in shadowy atmosphere and the haunted mood of post-war Berlin, Phoenix weaves a complex, Hitchcockian tale of a nation’s tragedy and a woman’s search for answers as it builds towards an unforgettable, heart-stopping climax. (Partially subtitled)

Following the film, we'll attempt to have a quiet discussion on the CBC patio

See you at the movie,

John

results.description:
CLOSED

Ahh, Malbec! 

Rich, generous, dark, BIG bold red wine. Malbec is very popular these days and deservedly so.

Most of what we find on the US market is from Argentina, and indeed many fine producers are from the Mendoza region in Argentina. But the varietal is French (!), traditionally grown in Cahors, a story book provincial town encircled by the Lot River north of Toulouse. And believe it or not I only recently learned that the Malbec varietal was once a minor component of the standard Bordeaux blend!


And what does one pair with such a rich red! Beef of course, preferably grilled. The wine lovers of Mendoza have  raised this pairing to an art form, seemingly eating beef for every meal. We will do our best to match their exuberance using the grilling resources at the venue and the grilling skills of our members.


This event will be a blind tasting, a bit more formal than some of our recent events. Anh and I are in the process of selecting several wines from the new and old worlds with price points ranging from $15-40. As we did on our 2014 France tour, we will taste the wines with and without food. Whom ever identifies all wines during the tasting will win a fantastic plastic trophy! Wow!? The results promise to be full of a surprises!

COST

$25 for wine due with RSVP 

Usual BostonWine refund policy applies. I will refund 100% up to 1 day in advance of the event. After that time, no refund. We are now using Meetup's payment service WePay. Let Jim know if there are any issues.

==> READ THIS! The event starts at 5pm; we will have greeters from 5 - 6pm, but security is tight and access shuts down at 6pm. You won't be able to get in if late!


POLICIES

Limited to 35 total including +1s; final spots reserved for newbies. Everyone must be a member of BostonWine or live at Hanover. RSVP early, but please don't RSVP unless you're sure that you can make it.

NOTE: As part of the RSVP process you will be asked to accept the group's Policies and Disclaimer (use a new web browser window to see the About Us section of our group's home page). You must answer "Yes" in this event's RSVP to attend. (Note, apparently some versions of the Meetup mobile app don't display this question -- in that case, RSVP with your phone and then use a web browser later on to update your RSVP). 

WHAT TO BRING 

==> Food that pairs well with Malbec <==

More ideas about what to bring shortly, but we certainly are interested in all guises of beef and cooks with grilling prowess. This most definitely is a carnivore event, however, I encourage members that don't eat red meat to bring other dishes so as to not miss out on all the fun.

WHERE

The event will be held in the Club Room of my apartment building, the Hanover CambridgePark. We have access to grilling facilities and outside firepit courtyard (but not pool). The event starts at 5pm; we will have greeters from 5 - 6pm, but security is tight and access shuts down at 6pm. 

Hanover CambridgePark 
160 CambridgePark Drive 
Club Room, 1st floor
Cambridge, MA 02140 

Phone:[masked]

T stop: Alewife (Red line)

Parking: No parking at the venue (yet!--latest word is guest parking will be ready sometime in Sept.) Best to take T.  Otherwise, park at Alewife T station ($7). Park and walk to main lobby of 160 and follow general directions. 

The Hanover CambridgePark is a new luxury apartment building complex in the Alewife area of Cambridge. It has a spacious club room where we'll be meeting, a spa-like pool, fitness center, pool, courtyard with fire pits, grills, high-end finishes, etc. Expect to see many more BostonWine events here in 2015!

For those interested in seeing a model apartment, leasing staff will be on hand before the event to do a tour (call ahead to be sure to get a spot). Remember to let them know that you're part of BostonWine. ;-) 

Anh, Thomas and I look forward to seeing you! 

-jim

results.description:
That's right...our next meetup is...

GARAGEBOX - Parking Garage Reverb Beatbox Session!!!

I discovered this place recently, and it's a spacious parking garage with amazing reverb.  This is no ordinary reverb.  I'm talking one-kick-drum-sound-breaks-the-glass-in-the-windows type reverb.  Seriously...this place is nuts!  I was up in this joint blasting beats for hours the other day!  You WON'T be disappointed with the sound in this place.  Even if you generally make rather quiet sounds, the reverb in this place will set your beats on fire!  No microphone needed.  

...and the best part?  There's a chill, super-classy rooftop garden to chill at once your lungs can't take any more beats!

...and the next best part?  There are hip bars all around to grab beers after a heavy session of beat-banging!  Bring your ID if you plan to get drinks.  Most places are sports-bars, so under 21 is also welcome; you can get food!

Here's the plan:

1.  Meetup, test out the sound in this amazing parking garage.

2.  Each person shares a 2-minute showcase.

3.  Each person describes a beatboxing sound, issue, or asks a question.

4.  Collaboration time!

5.  We split and drink good beer.

Make sure your RSVP all of your friends who you're bringing so we have an accurate count.

See you there!

-GREEN
results.how_to_find_us: Get off at Kendall/MIT station on the Red Line.  Go through the Cambridge Center and into the parking garage.  We'll meet at the top of the garage at the rooftop garden, then go into the parking garage to get some crazy reverb going.
results.name: GARAGEBOX - Parking Garage Reverb Session

results.description:
We will be active and walk from Sam Adams Brewery to Franklin Park and complete the Circuit Path (2.25 mile loop), then continue to Jamaica Pond and complete 1 lap there (1.5 miles). 

-Franklin Park is filled with hidden treasures, old stone ruins, a beautiful pond, walking paths and trails, playgrounds, and playing fields.  

-Jamaica Pond is a kettle pond, part of the Emerald Necklace of parks in Boston.  The pond and park are in the Jamaica Plain neighborhood of Boston, close to the border of Brookline.  

http://www.franklinparkcoalition.org/about-franklin-park/places/walking-loop/

results.description:
There's rain in the forecast Saturday - that's a good day to have dinner and see a movie. We'll have dinner first, then go and see the movie. See below for a description of the movie/documentary. It got great reviews on Rotten Tomatoes. It's debuting this weekend in Boston Common's theaters for a limited run.


We will see the 9:25 pm show.


This RSVP is for both dinner and movie unless you indicate otherwise when you RSVP.


As always please remember to update your RSVP if your plans change. And try to avoid last minute drop outs. We appreciate your cooperation.


Here is a description about the movie.


In February 2013, Anaïs Bordier, a French fashion student living in London, stumbled upon a YouTube video featuring Samantha Futerman, an actress in Los Angeles, and was struck by their uncanny resemblance. After discovering they were born on the same day in Busan, Korea and both put up for adoption, Anaïs reached out to Samantha via Facebook.


In Twinsters, we follow Samantha and Anaïs' journey into sisterhood, witnessing everything from their first meeting, to their first trip back to Korea where their separation took place. Twinsters explores the meaning of family and connection through a story that would have been impossible just ten years ago without the creation of YouTube and Facebook.

results.description:
Bordeaux, in the south-west of France, needs lots of introduction to people like Roy, despite his interest in wine. One of the world's most prolific wine regions, it also manages to rank among the most famous and prestigious, despite recent years. The secrets of Bordeaux's wine success are its three trump cards: Chinese buyers, marketing, and some delicious wines.

Let's get together and see what its all about!

Bring a bottle of Bordeaux in the $20-30 range, $10 and 4 glasses.

The address will be mailed out to attendees a day or two before the event.

results.description:

One of the world's most prolific wine regions, it also manages to rank among the most famous and prestigious. The secrets of Bordeaux's wine success are its three trump cards: diversity, quality and quantity.  

Let's get together and explore the variety this region offers!

Bring a bottle of Bordeaux in the $20-30 range, $10 and 4 glasses.

results.description:
What's cool, hip, not your Dad, and won Boston A-List's Best Night of Comedy? ITS THE MENDOZA LINE!!!!!

Every Saturday night live from the back room of the The Dugout Cafe (722 Comm Ave), Jenny Chalikian, John Baglio, Julia Claire, and Zach "Zack" Armentrout bring you the biggest baddest bestiest comedians from Boston and beyond. And guess the fuck what? Its only FIVE DOLLARS. With drink specials as far as the eye can see and free popcorn, this intimate atmosphere is the perfect place to take in some meaningful laughs

This week is a very special episode: It's local comedy superhero DAN CROHN's birthday! He's slingin' jokes with his funniest friends all night, and guess what--by some clerical error YOU'RE HIS FRIEND, TOO! It's a celebration FOR THE AGES, for MOST AGES, about ONE GUY'S SPECIFIC AGE! Don't miss it!

Featuring the comedic talents of:

DAVE MCDONOUGH (winner, Boston Comedy Festival)

JIM WHITMAN (utter perfection)

DAN BOULGER (winner, Boston Comedy Festival)

SEAN SULLIVAN (Comedy Central)

MIKE WHITMAN (senior superlative, Best Smile)

and

GUEST HOST DAN CROHN (Last Comic Standing, birthday boy)

Buy your tix now to guarantee a seat as spaces are limited. We don't want to turn you away again, Joel!

https://www.eventbrite.com/e/the-mendoza-line-bostons-best-weekly-comedy-showcase-tickets-15228587114

You've seen Kevin Quigley's hilarious storytelling show, Wild Memory Nation, all over Boston: Johnny D's Comedy Presents, Phoenix Landing Comedy Presents, ImprovBoston SketchHaus, even in a featured slot at the Women in Comedy Festival. Now see what happens when the funniest true stories get the late night treatment ... and get a little bit naughty.

NIGHT MOVES features some of the best comedians telling the funniest stories about the most ticklish subject of all: sex. From sex-positive hilarity to the most intimate of disasters, NIGHT MOVES brings you the saucy side of Boston comedy. True sex stories, real funny. Only at ImprovBoston!

Your 8/22 lineup: Johnny Burns, Emily Ruskowski, Diana Valentine, Mike Sweeney, Julia Claire, and Lauren Walleser!

venue.name: The New England Center for Homeless Veterans

results.description:
I volunteer a couple of times a month serving lunch at the shelter. Great group of men and women who have served our country and have come back needing a little help. The Center, which was started by a Veteran, provides housing, health care, social services, food, as well as a multitude of other services for our returning heroes. They have volunteer groups come in on weekends and do breakfast service. We don't provide the food, just smiles and friendly faces. The serving starts at 7:15am and we would be done by around 9.  We have gone as a group several times and hope to keep this up monthly, there's a limit to 6 servers each time. It's really a wonderful time. Some of the ladies asked about baking/bringing something. I also spoke with the head of the kitchen....just avoid things with nuts because of allergies. Hope to see you all then! We can carpool, it's near the Orange line and if you drive in you can park right in front. Also remember a hat, you need to have your head/hair covered to serve.

 My telephone number if you have any questions or have a last minute change to status is[masked]

2 things:
1. Since this is a popular event, I'd like to ask that you only sign up only if you are able to get up early on a Sunday.  There will be several Sundays throughout the year I'll actually take myself off as well so that opens up one spot. On the days I cook, I'll also open it up to have 7 servers so that more can come.
2. To prevent the # of no shows we've had, I'm going to just let everyone know that if you know show, I will remove you from future volunteer opportunities with the Center. I've hated the times when due to no shows, the Vets have had to step in to help, especially because there are often individuals that were on the wait list and didn't have the opportunity to show. If you cannot attend, please RSVP no ahead of time, or at the very least, just call or text me if you aren't well the morning of the shift, just so I know and can get them to provide help when I get there. My telephone # is[masked]-1526. Those letting me know that they can't make a day ahead of time won't be considered a no show.

Thank you for your ongoing support. I appreciate it and I know that the Veterans do as well.

results.description:
This hike is suitable for intermediate level and better hikers. We will hike at least 7 miles in one of the Boston area's hidden gems. AND in the midst of the hike... we will swim.  So either put a suit in your day pack OR if you have quick dry hiking clothes... that's a great option on a summer day.

As with all Connecticut Hiking Alliance events, please do not use the "no rsvp" unless you previously rsvp'd yes and need to change your plans. We make this request because all rsvp responses become emails to the leaders. If you have not signed up as a yes, then we already know you are a "no" so please conserve on the emails. Other Meetup groups may have a different rsvp preference. 

For our hike:


Vertical Rise:  1370 ft.

Distance:  at LEAST 7 miles

Trailhead:  42 degrees 13'26" N, 71 degrees 04"12" W

Directions:  From the junction of MA 28 and I-93 (exit 5), drive 1.4 miles north ON MA-28 to the first traffic light at Chickatawbut Road.  Turn right.  Park immediately in a small gravel lot on the right. 


Carpool/Caravan:   DEPART Enfield Park and Ride at 7:34 AM.  Yes... 7:34 AM departure.  Which means you need to arrive before that time so that we can get into each others cars and move gear and such.  The Enfield Park and Ride is on I-91 Exit 48 at the Mall  parking lot near Macys in Enfield.  Follow the signs.  It's easy.

The DCR Blue Hills Reservation stretches over 7,000 acres from Quincy to Dedham, Milton to Randolph, providing a green oasis in an urban environment. Rising above the horizon, Great Blue Hill reaches a height of 635 feet, the highest of the 22 hills in the Blue Hills chain. From the rocky summit visitors can see over the entire metropolitan area. With its scenic views, varied terrain and 125 miles of trails, the Blue Hills Reservation offers year-round enjoyment for the outdoor enthusiast.

Link:  Link to Blue Hills


The Blue Hills were so named by early European explorers who, while sailing along the coastline, noticed the bluish hue on the slopes when viewed from a distance. More than ten thousand years before those Europeans arrived, Native Americans made their home in the hills. The Natives referred to themselves as Massachusett, or "people of the great hills". Eventually the Europeans began settling in this region. The colonists built houses and barns, cleared fields for crops and livestock and logged the hillsides for lumber.


Legal Stuff: By clicking on "Count me in" or "Yes" for this event you agree, warrant, and covenant as follows: In consideration for accepting this entry, I, the registrant, intending to be legally bound, for myself, my heirs, my executors and administrators, do waive and release any and all rights for damages I may have against any parties or persons connected with the Connecticut Hiking Alliance for and related to the above listed event. I attest and verify that I am physically fit to participate in any portion of this above listed event. I grant the Connecticut Hiking Alliance permission to use any photographs, film or videotapes of this event for any purpose. 

I am participating in this event with the understanding that manyphotos will be taken and it is likely that I will appear in one or more photos. And the Connecticut Hiking Alliance takes a LOT of photos! And we post many many! Be forewarned. If you are in the witness protection program, this group is not for you. 

Apres hike:  Yes!   Our most likely option is...  LaScala (Italian - no credit cards)  1070 North Main Street - Randolph MA  (4 minutes from trailhead).

Equipment/Hiking Wear: As with all Connecticut Hiking Alliance hikes, hiking shoes/hiking boots are a must as we hike on hiking trails not walking paths. Proper clothing is also important; please dress appropriately and be prepared for changing conditions taking layers off or putting them on may be needed during the stretch of a hike and perhaps facing a pop up shower. 

Please bring a roll of lifesavers.

Cotton is NOT appropriate wear when executing activities where you sweat and cool therefore please select your hiking apparel with this in mind... denim is off limits as it becomes heavy and uncomfortable hindering your ability to hike and keep pace with the group. 

If you have trouble on the hike, you will negatively impact the enjoyment for the rest of the group. If you are uncertain as to what clothing or items are considered hiking wear, please email me directly, or email any of the co-organizers. We will also be able to share referrals to suppliers of both new and gently used hiking apparel and supplies. 

Food and Drink: Snacks - especially proteins and sugars and water. You don't want to run out of water. If you aren't properly nourished you WILL have trouble on the hike and will negatively impact the enjoyment for the rest of the group.

NOTE: Please make any general comments regarding how to improve or alter the overall processes of all the outings in the DISCUSSIONS tab. Requests for autographs should go through my marketing coordinator. Questions and comments to this event should be posted below. To communicate with a specific individual member - please email them directly (through meet up) rather than posting comments. Postings become announcements to everyone which can be annoying. The postings to the site should be topics that would be pertinent to all members. Meetup sites all have email functions for conversations between members.

results.description:
This venue honors Charles River Boating as well as Boating in Boston season passes.  Some may have purchased groupons or living social coupons for either of these places.

We'll paddle the waters of Boston Harbor at Carson Beach which can be reached by Red Line or car. Please bring cash. We'll learn the basics on shore then plan to put them in the water for 1 to 1.5 hour which is plenty of time for a workout and to learn all you need to know. If you already know how to kayak, you are welcome to join us too.   


After we kayak, we can relax on the beach, walk.  Also, there is a fast take-out place at Castle Island (about a 25-30 minute walk) where you can get food and  or ice cream).  Food served at a reasonable price include hot dogs, hamburgers, fish, fries, onion rings...  There are bathrooms/changing areas available on the beach.

Park in the Carson Beach Lot or on Babe Ruth Avenue or take the Red Line (best way) to JFK and walk 9 minutes to McCormick Bathhouse, Carson Beach, South Boston. 


If there is a wait for kayaks, some will start kayaking while others watch from the beach or walk Castle Island. Then, the second group will go out while the first group watches or walks.  

Single kayaks are $15/hour; tandems are  $20.  We may have to take tandems if there are no more singles available.

If you have any questions,  can post in comment section.

Kayaking is easier than canoeing and much safer than it has been in the past. Wearing a rubber skirt and rolling the kayak is no longer required.
http://boatinginboston.com/

We'll meet at these tables (see photo above) which is across from Boating in Boston where we rent kayaks in the brick building below (McCormick Bathhouse). 


Carson Beach

This sandy beach, owned and maintained by the Commonwealth's Department of Conservation and Recreation, is one of the best swimming beaches in the area, with nearby public amenities and great views of the Harbor. New sand, new walkways, benches, lighting, shade shelters and award winning landscaping have helped to make Carson Beach a popular destination. The recently renovated Edward J. McCormack Bathhouse, one of the first facilities completed as part of the "Back to the Beaches" effort, has restrooms, changing rooms, showers, drinking water fountains, chess tables, and bocce courts. In addition, it hosts first aid and lifeguard functions. "Mother's Rest" and its fishing pier have also been rehabilitated, making for a beautiful picnic area with a fantastic view of the Harbor.

HOW TO KAYAK


STEP 1 Gear up

Choose a kayak suited for learning. A sit-on-top model is best for beginners and what we'll be using. Wear a life jacket.

STEP 2 Get in


Step into the kayak, crouching to keep your center of gravity low, and quickly sit down. On a beach, lay the paddle across the cockpit and rest one end on the sand to steady the boat as you get in.

Lean back comfortably in the seat as you paddle. This will help the boat stay stable.

STEP 3 Paddle

Hold the paddle with an overhand grip, thumbs under, and dip one side into the water. Pull down and back with one hand while pushing forward with the other hand. Dip the paddle straight in and pull it back even with your hips. Then dip the other side.

Paddle with a smooth, rhythmic motion. Use your torso muscles and sit up straight without leaning into your strokes.

STEP 4 Turn

Paddle on only one side to turn the kayak in an opposite direction. Or use the paddle like a rudder, dragging it on the side you want to turn toward.

STEP 5 Practice falling out or turning the kayak over in water

Strap the paddle to a kayak, then grab the middle of the kayak. Kick to pull yourself onto a sit-on model, which are the easy ones we'll be using.

STEP 6 Watch conditions

Be aware of water and weather conditions. Paddle at an angle to the wind until you're near the shore before continuing.

STEP 7 Know the rules and your limits

Learn the rules that determine right-of-way on the water. Give the right of way to less maneuverable watercraft.

STEP 8 Get out.

Use your balance and take your time.

Remember: Your Event Organizers are volunteers. You are responsible for your own safety and enjoyment. results.description:
This Week's Ride: In Search of Llamas


10:00 for 38, and 52 miles

More details on the CRW Calendar: http://bit.ly/Iw67FE

Description:

All rides are primarily along quiet back roads. Short ride passes through Dover, Sherborn, and Holliston. Long ride extends to Ashland. We'll pass by several farms in the area (may see some Llamas, Burros, and Horses in addition to the usual farm animals). Short ride varies from flat to medium hills. Long ride adds hills in Holliston. LUNCH stop for all rides is in Holliston at the Coffee Haven 

This is the arrow to follow for the ride:

This is a re-occuring ride every Sunday beginning in April, with the organized and marked rides of CRW (Charles River Wheelmen). The picture above is from one of last years rides. Don't let the # of RSVPs here fool you, these rides are always well atended usually with over 25 riders of all abilities.

The distances and routes vary every week. We'll have "No Drop Rule" so you won't have to worry about getting lost or keeping up. Ride with us if you ride anywhere from 15 to 20 MPH.

Always bring two spare tubes, and your preferred hydration and nutrition. We don't typically stop for lunch but depending on the ride, there are sometimes options to stop for a bit. Before riding it's good practice to get your bike tuned. Remember to dress for the elements.

Also CRW organizes a Spring Century, a Summer Century called Climb to the Clouds, and a Fall Century. All of the Centuries have organized food and water stops. I'm hoping to get a group committed to building up to these Century rides.

results.description:
Although the weather forecast has changed for the better and it looks like we should get a bike ride in tomorrow without rain, Tougas Family Farm will not be open very long so this destination is no longer an option.


This means that my mission to cycle to all the ice cream shops in the greater Boston area continues. Starting at the Framingham High School parking lot, we will ride about 30 miles round trip to Trombatta Farms for ice cream. While this is a no person left behind ride, please be sure you can maintain at least 12 - 13 mph average speed on rolling hills of Boston's western suburbs. We will stop and regroup at major turns.


What you need: a helmet, spare tube, 1 - 2 water bottles, and a sense of fun and adventure. No ear buds or headphones please. I cannot say if they sell lunch food at Trombetta Farms, but can confirm that they have ice cream, so if you think this is more than sufficient as a nutritious and satisfying lunch, then you're all set (really, ice cream is a complete food!). Otherwise, you might want to bring something with you to eat at lunch.

Arrive at 10am at Framingham High School parking lot for a 10:15am departure. Look for a white Subaru Crosstrek with a bike rack on the roof.

results.description:
PURCHASE TICKETS HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/arduino-workshop-tickets-17886093788

Instructor: Pooja Mistry


This workshop is for anyone who has never played around with Arduino before and those who have played around a little bit but aren’t entirely sure about how the basics work. It’s easier than you think!

We will put together basic single component electrical circuits, learn about analog and digital, input and output, basic programming concepts, practice very basic Serial communication, and briefly cover basic virtual prototyping.

In case you haven’t noticed the key word here is "basic."

Students will create three simple circuits highlighting analog and digital forms of input and output. Get started with the Arduino programming environment; briefly discuss programming and virtual prototyping.

Concepts that will be covered include:

Using a breadboard
Ohm’s Law
Digital and Analog
Input and Output
Arduino programming environment basics
Serial Monitor usage with text, variables and pin states

The $99 workshop fee includes a Sparkfun Inventor's Kit students get to take home afterward; the kit normally sells online for $99.95. Members of Lowell Makes may participate in the workshop for $75.

To ensure adequate instructor-student engagement, this workshop is limited to 10 students.
results.name: Arduino Workshop

By signing up you agree to the Mosaic Outdoor Mountain Club release of Liability below.
We will hike the Red Dot Trail to BUCK HILL, pause there to rest and enjoy the view, and then follow the Blue Skyline Trail (steep rocky hills) back to our cars.
  it is approximately 4 miles, and includes going up and down 3 steep, rocky hills (the Skyline part of the hike): Buck (492'), Boyce (377'), and Tucker (436').
The pace will be moderate, definitely not a gentle amble in the park, so if you are looking for a slow walk, this is not the hike for you.
We will wait for everyone on this hike, so the pace of the hike will be held to that of the slowest hiker. If you break away from the Group at any point and hike ahead of us, then you are on your own. I will be on point and we will stay together as a Group.
Please make sure you are wearing appropriate shoes - hiking boots (we will cross three streams!). Remember to bring energy snacks to keep your endurance up, and plenty of water. You also should have a headlamp or flashlight with you.
No dogs are allowed on this hike.
Contact Mike at[masked]

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
This session we will focus on Acro (Acrobatics) and tumbling basics. This will help us enter the world of freerunning, and develop our spatial awareness aka going upside down!


What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 

This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

Are you an old pro, and would like to ensure that you are covering your design, marketing, and delivery basics?  


Or are you a potential workshop organizer with a passion, and would like to design a solid workshop and explore a marketing plan?  

Maybe you'd like some day to co-lead with someone?  Or to offer someone else's work here in Boston? Or maybe you're just curious now -- what does it take to create a successful workshop?

This one day workshop will go over the nuts and bolts of creating and offering a two hour workshop (on whatever subject excites you.):
- Designing the Workshop  
- Marketing the Workshop
- Delivering the Workshop 


You will walk away with a solid first-draft design of a workshop and a plan for implementing and marketing it. 

This course is designed for current PGN leaders and PGN hosts, as well as for those who would like to investigate being workshop organizers, leaders, and hosts.   The lessons apply to any workshop, even if you do not offer it on PGN, and even if it is not a "personal growth" workshop.

You will generate and test your concept and select your target segment.  We'll discuss the logistics of setting up the meeting, including pricing and timing. 


You'll tackle the hardest part of creating a workshop -- getting people into seats.  You'll construct good titles and copy, select alternative channels to reach your target segments, time your advertising pulses, and handle sales.

You'll create a solid design for the evening, with a good flow through the evening that will build trust, engage participants and help them to apply your lessons to their lives. We will overview dos and don'ts of running a meeting.  And you will practice the top four facilitation tools of a workshop (dyads, mingles, CEP, and sharing). 

Price


The price of our first train the trainer event is $45, if you sign up between now and August 15th.  This is a special price to make sure that all PGN leaders share basic skills.

Location

This event takes place at the new center for The Ollin Institute, which focuses on the personal, collaborative, and collectives skills and perspectives needed for our evolving lives and planet. The Ollin Institute is located on Newbury Street in Boston, near the Hynes Convention Center. It is available by T, commuter train (Back Bay Station), and driving. There are several parking garages available. Also, participants who would rather not drive can park and ride from several locations. For a full listing of parking, driving, and commuter options go here.

Leaders

Trish Blain has been a social mission entrepreneur since 1989,  is the founder of The Ollin Institute and several meet up groups, including EROS: Exploring Love, Sex and Soul, Soul Experiments and Entrepreneur Allies. She owned and operated The Whole Heath Expo from[masked] and she has lead over 200 events and retreats.

A renaissance teacher/leader, her passion and expertise lies in the intersection points of spirituality, sexuality, social entrepreneurship, creativity, and evolutionary consciousness.

Dennis Pratt is the founder of the Personal Growth Network and of the Heartbeat Salons.  Honored by his MIT professors and awarded a fellowship, Dennis specialized in the marketing of start-ups at MIT's Sloan School of Management.  

A past serial entrepreneur, Dennis now volunteers to help the hundred or so personal growth leaders on PGN to design, market, and lead events.  His goal is to make Greater Boston the destination region for personal growth, and is looking to train vibrant leaders who will transform the region, sending ripples through the world.
results.name: PGN: The Design, Marketing and Delivery of a Workshop

Non-GMO food and eco-friendly vendors will be there :)

results.description:
Massive Bowling

Pool/Skeeball/Shuffleboard

Extravaganza!

Hey everyone!

It's time again for our big monthly bowling event at Kings! We always have a great time and we always pack the place. If you've attended before, you know THIS EVENT IS AWESOME, RIGHT?! Of course you do!

FAQ:

Q: Is this really free?
A: Yes! It's really free!

- Free Bowling! 
- Free Shoe Rentals! 
- Free Pool! 
- Free Skeeball! 
- Free Shuffleboard!

Q: Can I bring my kids?
A: Yes! Kids are welcome! I usually have lanes 1 & 2 set up with bumpers for them.

Q: What's the best way to get there?
A: Honestly, taking the T is. See the Getting There section below.

Q: C'mon, this is really all free? What's the catch?
A: Yes, it's really all free and there is no catch! Simply put, I'm awesome. lol : )

RSVP now!

RSVP ETIQUETTE

1. This is a really popular event, and we do count the RSVP's for this, so please RSVP in one group only, as this allows for an accurate count and staff is hired according to this number.

2. RSVP RESPONSIBLY! There are many people in the habit of no-showing and it hurts these events! Don't be that person! Only RSVP if you can go and update your RSVP if you can't make it. You fellow group members and organizers are counting on you to show up. : )

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Get ready for a great time with Boston's best socialites!

See you there… :)

~Matt

P.S. We have the entire Royal Room and bowling lanes 1-10 for this event! Find us inside!

❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤❤

Getting There:

Taking The T: You can get off at the Hynes Convention Center on the B, C, & D Green Line trains and walk the 2 blocks over, or you can get off at the Prudential Mall station on the E Green Line train and walk through the Pru and the Sheraton to get there.

Driving: Parking can be tough and expensive. There is a garage right next door, but it's $29. You can find on street parking, but that's tough on Sunday mornings. If you want to drive and park, I suggest you get to the area 30-45 minutes early and start looking. Newbury, Hereford, Boylston, and Scotia Streets are all places I look and find parking.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for me, Matt, and the signs that mark our lanes will say Social In Boston.

Fee is $11. You should bring your racket and  shoes, or you can rent racket for $5

PLEASE NOTE: Our weekend MJ sessions are usually in Saugus, not Danvers.

Please RSVP for this event so we can be sure to grab enough tables and bring enough Mah Jongg sets!  Newcomers to American style Mah Jongg are welcome! Thanks!

Note that MJ is usually played with 4 people, although it can be played with 2 or 3 as well, with some adjustment to the rules. If the number of RSVPs is not a multiple of 4, then we can decide whether to have multiple tables or have some sit out of some games and observe OR play a rack with another person. (This is a great way to learn!)

results.description:
Hi Late Risers!

Join your friendly organizers, Laura & John for our favorite inside activity - Games, Cards & Conversation. This event is cross posted with Cards & Conversation Meetup Group.

Parking - Free on Main street. Also behind the restaurant in the Shaws market plaza - No restrictions. We're a friendly group that enjoy socializing about games, local events and every day news topics. Card games like Kitty whist are most popular, but we also are open to many casual games. Examples are tile, number and letter games. Train games like ticket to ride and railway. We're open to all. Bring a game to play and or to teach. We will chat and have coffee first, then we will play in groups of 4 or 5. Laura

results.description:
Kimono Flashmob for Peace:

On Sunday, August 23rd, 2015, Women of the World is organizing a gathering for peace in light of the 70th Anniversary of the Hiroshima /Nagasaki atomic bombings.


In Japan, the month of August is a time of reflection, a time to recommit to a world where peace is necessary and possible.

The idea is to have a Freeze Flashmob with hundreds of people, all wearing Yukata or Kimono (traditional Japanese outfits). Click here for a Freeze Flashmob example:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jwMj3PJDxuo

After the Flashmob, the participants (and audience) will join together for a song/chant for peace.


Besides the Flashmob and the impact we hope it will have, we hope to educate our volunteers/participants, so they can carry the message of peace forward, be it through songwriting, art, dance, drama, creative writing, spoken word, or simply as voices for peace. We welcome and encourage ALL AGES & ALL NATIONALITIES to join us!


Possible Rehearsal Date:
Saturday, August 22nd, 2015 from 6 to 8pm.
Venue TBD
(We will teach you the peace song)

Flashmob Date:
Sunday, August 23rd, 2015 - afternoon event

(We're keeping the exact time & location secret until the event)


Dressing in Japanese costumes will begin earlier in the day.

Alternate rain date:
Sunday, August 30th, 2015 at 1pm

***IMPORTANT: You MUST register in advance.

For Questions/Info contact: www.WomenOfTheWorldMusic.com

Register HERE:
https://goo.gl/29HJ6I
results.name: Kimono Flashmob for Peace

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll take the turf if it's available (south end of the park)  Otherwise check the grass fields around the middle of the park.
results.name: Sunday Afternoon @ Joe Moakley Park

No RSVP is necessary, feel free to just show up.

results.description:
The first picnic was a lot of fun, so let's have another one! :D

Come to Boston Common for a casual picnic in the park - anyone is welcome! We will be somewhere inside the area shown on the map below. We will probably sit north of the gazebo. When we find a spot, Rachel will make a comment with a GPS image of the exact location.

Boston Common is located right next to all of these T stops: Park Street (Red Line & Green Line), Boylston (Green Line), Chinatown (Orange Line), Downtown Crossing (Red & Orange)

This is a potluck-style picnic, so if you can, please bring some food or (non-alcoholic) drink to share. If you have any games to play outdoors, those would be fun to bring, too! Football and frisbee were popular last time.

Even if you can't bring anything, don't worry! You're still welcome to join! I hope to see you there! 

Click here for a larger map.


If it rains on August 23th, this event will be moved to August 30th.
results.how_to_find_us: We will be in a shady spot somewhere inside the area shown on the map. If you can't find the group, please contact Rachel!
results.name: Summer Picnic #2 @ Boston Common!

results.description:
Groups are wonderful! They help bolster your commitment and motivation, they supply you with opportunities to get ahead on your journey, and they provide support from the other members.
But when it comes to EFT, groups are even more wonderful! Not only is there a synergy created between the tappers increasing the potency of healing received, but even when the tapping isn't related to your particular problem, you still bet to borrow benefits from it!

And after the effort, relaxation! A potluck will be held after the tapping circle. More tappers will join us in socializing, mingling and discussing healing and many other topics, I'm sure!

Attendance is not required, you can choose to go to either one event, but keep in mind that the amount of people allowed in the tapping circle is limited to 10. If you need to cancel your reservation, please do so at least 3 days in advance so that someone else can come in to the event...
results.name: EFT Tapping Circle

results.description:
This is the kick-off of a neighborhood sketch series where we will skip the monuments in favor of the "grain" of the city. 

Beacon Hill is a very recognizable and characterful neighborhood, climbing up from the commons, and dropping back down towards the Charles. Hills can create special challenges for drawing perspective as well.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=t3jdEMxrNw4


note how the hill has a different vanishing point than the rest of the perspective. 

We will meet at 2pm in front of the Church-like building at 70 Charles St. There is an excellent Cafe inside. Then we will walk up the hill into the neighborhood and disperse. We will reconvene at 4pm at the cafe's outdoor seating to share our work and chat.

Looking forward to another great sketching session! Hope to see you there.

(PS I'll be watching the weather; be prepared for an update or at least an umbrella)
results.how_to_find_us: Chris will have a red backpack (206) 349-3669
results.name: Let's Sketch! Beacon Hill Neighborhood

results.description:
Summer is quickly coming to an end, but the free events in Boston never cease to amaze me! As a green food enthusiast, this event really excites me!

Either Sarah or I OR Sarah and I will be at the venue a few minutes prior to the given time. IM either of us if you need to find us.

The 8th Annual Boston GreenFest ! This is the region's largest FREE multicultural environmental music festival. 

It is a celebration of life and possibility, providing you with ideas and experiences that can shape your life and the life of your community. It will showcase the many ways green living can make a positive impact on our world, city, neighborhoods and each of us. 

Non-GMO Food and Eco-friendly vendors will be there :) 

http://www.bostongreenfest.org/ 

And to burn some of the Calories I consume, I will be doing the following walk hosted by Sarah C.

http://www.meetup.com/Finding-Pedro/events/224296762/
results.name: Boston GreenFest!

results.description:
This is a "low intermediate and up" level meetup. We play on grass on a men's height net. We will start with warm-up and a hitting line, followed by 6:6 play.

Low Intermediate -- players who can consistently bump, set, spike, and serve. Moderate pace; laid-back game.

Location: Grass fields at Sidney and Pacific Street in Cambridge.

Access by T: Central Square stop. Walk down Mass Ave towards MIT, make a right on Sidney Street, and walk down about four blocks to Pacific Street. It's about a 5-10 minute walk from the T stop.

Parking: There are spots on one side of Tudor Street between Sidney and Brookline that are free to park at on weekends. It is the side of the street opposite the side with the parking meters.

We have had a long waitlist the past few Sundays, so please make sure that you RSVP only if you can come, and show up on time if you have RSVP'ed. Due to high demand, we are putting in place a priority rule for those who show up consistently and on time. If there is a waitlist, no-shows from the previous week get lower priority. It counts as a no-show for waitlist purposes if you change your RSVP to "no" less than 24 hours before the start time or arrive late for the actual game after warm-up.
results.name: Cambridge Outdoor Volleyball (Low Intermediate+)

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email.


(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru
results.name: An Introduction to Inner Engineering--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Come join Cambridge residents and business owners in an open and casual environment to discuss your questions, concerns suggestions and vision for Cambridge and its government.

All are welcome and there is no agenda. This event is free and is taking place at Grafton Street Pub & Grill. There is a cash bar if you would like to order food or drink.

These Round Table events are organized by Kim Courtney and Xavier Dietrich, two Cambridge residents who are candidates for City Council. From their experience, there are not enough venues and opportunities to voice questions and concerns about the City and its operation, and they are interested in hearing from everyone who would like to share their perspective.

Please be on time since this meeting is only one hour.  This meeting is limited to 20 people so that everyone can contribute. Since space is limited, please only sign up if you can join us, and cancel if something comes up.
results.name: Round Table - Share Questions & Concerns about Cambridge City Government

results.description:
Pretty much exactly what it sounds like. Come get high on sugar. As the point of this event is to eat candy, no particular other activity has been planned, but if the weather is nice we can go out for a walk to repent for our sugary sins, or we can play games or watch anime in the house.

BRING CANDY TO HELP FILL THE SUSHI. If you don't you may be eating something pretty boring.

Potential candy ideas:
Swedish fish
Mini M&Ms
Skittles
Reese’s Pieces
Gummy Worms
twizzlers

Rice krispie treats and fruit roll-ups will be provided/made on site, but pitch in with the candy! Make it a surprise for everyone! Rice krispie treats will be made with margarine. 

I probably won't kick you out at 6, think of it as a soft ending time. I live on the third floor, stairs only. Please plan accordingly. 

Plenty of street parking or about 5min walk from the 73 busline stops out of Harvard square. Take the 73 ~2 miles and get off at Oxford street or Marian street. Exact address will be posted prior to meetup. 

PLEASE un-RSVP if you can’t make it. It’s pretty rude to say you are coming and not show up.

Address is 68 Dartmouth St #3 in Belmont. If you need to reach me call[masked]

results.description:
</a>

Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

<a href="https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com">https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com


(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 39-49-1F/1M SPOT LEFT

results.description:
{Unannounced} 

PGN's leadership meeting brings together Greater Boston personal growth leaders to discuss how to work together to accelerate the growth of personal growth in our region.

At our last meeting, not only did we initiate the expansion of the Heartbeat Salons and start planning the Expo, but our top leaders connected together deeply and informatively.  Several working alliances were forged.  The biggest request coming out of that meeting was for more such leadership meetings so that we could work better together.

It is time for another review of who we are, of where we would like to lead the personal growth community, of strategies to get there, and of how we can work together.


We will greet each other.  We will review recent successes, and acknowledge areas where we did not have as much movement.

The core of the meeting will focus on our next major thrusts, including
* Creating a series of "Train the Trainer" classes that will teach, review, and expand facilitation and marketing skills.
* A PGN blog where you leaders can regularly share your ideas with the larger personal growth population
* A major expansion of our community through social networking.

Other Leadership Meeting that Day:
This meeting will be taking place an hour after the Nuts and Bolts of Marketing and Facilitating a Workshop training to accommodate those of you who would like to attend both.


Food: 
Please come having eaten.  There are plenty of places on Newbury Street to grab something to eat.


Those attending both the earlier Nuts and Bolts of Marketing ... a Workshop class and this leadership strategy meeting, will have an hour in between to catch dinner together, and to return for this leadership meeting.

Location
This event takes place on Newbury Street in Boston, near the Hynes Convention Center. It is available by T, commuter train (Back Bay Station), and driving. There are several parking garages available. Also, participants who would rather not drive can park and ride from several locations. For a full listing of parking, driving, and commuter options go here.
results.how_to_find_us: At Karma Yoga Studios, above Trident Bookstore, close to the T with lots of parking garages around (See link to parking and commuter hints)
results.name: PGN: Greater Boston Personal Growth Leadership Meeting

results.description:
We had a pretty good game of Successors last weekend, and I feel like I want to take it on the road again while the rules are fresh in my head. Both veterans and total newbies are welcome to try this out -- it's a fun, lively multi-player game with a lot of nastiness and treachery to go around.

Babylon. 323 BC.

The mighty emperor Alexander the Great, fresh off of conquering Asia Minor, Mesopotamia, Syria, Persia and Egypt, and spreading Hellenistic civilization to the four quarters of his realm, sits down, gets his drink on, and dies around two weeks later.

Bummer.

Double bummer is that our man Alex, still being quite the young fellow, did not leave an heir who was of age. The theory is that his generals will loyally keep the peace and protect his heirs and other family members until they are old enough to take the reins of his vast empire, and CERTAINLY NOT try to carve off a mighty kingdom of their very own from some choice bits that just happen to be exactly where their loyal troops just happen to be standing.

That's the theory. History teaches how well this theory usually works in practice.

In Successors, you control two of those generals, and you have a choice: you can be a loyal champion of the late emperor's family and gain Legitimacy Points by protecting the young heirs and carrying Alexander's funeral cart from Babylon back to the Macedonian capital city, Pella, or you can stake out a position as a successor to Alexander's throne (by right of We Can Beat You Up) by gaining control of provinces and claiming Victory Points. You can win instantly by passing a VP or LP threshold, you can win by controlling one of the heirs at the start of the appropriate turn AND having the most VP and LP combined, or you can win at the end of five turns by having the most VP.

To me, this sounds like Game of Thrones with fewer nude scenes but better hummous. Does it sound good to you? Let's play.

We'll be meeting at Pandemonium for this one. It's two blocks from the Central Square Red Line stop. The Open Gaming begins at Pandemonium at 6 but I'd like to get there a little early (this hasn't historically been an issue, most of the time) to aid in teaching the game with enough time left over to play the thing, so please shoot for 5:30 if at all possible.
results.name: Let's Play Successors! Again!

FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

<a href="http://www.meetup.com/atwysspeeddating/"></a>
results.name: Speeddating Ages 27-37 --2F/1M SPOTS LEFT

results.description:
Ron's on vacation, but the walk is still on.  

Let's join 20+ others from six other walking groups for:

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.

We'll go out to dinner at a local pub or chinese restaurant - you can get a decent dinner for under $10.

Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there. We'll be next to the bridge, on the pond side of Huron Ave,at the intersection of Aberdeen Ave.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

Shangri La is located at 149 Belmont Street, Belmont - please let the host know if you're coming, so we can get the right sized table.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :8/23@6:30

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
