results.description:
Come join us for a screening of the movie that got me started on my quest to understand more and more about healthy eating and weight loss!

     This movie explores the relationship between diet and degenerative diseases--including obesity--and interestingly enough, when what we eat changes into something healthy, the weight comes off by itself!

     For a while I've known that when we focus on diet, we miss the point.  A diet by definition has a beginning and an end--and then, after it ends, more often as not, it's back to business as usual, and we typically regain the weight we lose.


     You know the drill: you lose the weight, things are fine for a while, you think the problem is under control, you try one or two bites of things like ice cream here and there, then more, then even more, and pretty soon, you are off to the races.


     What we need is a new approach, a lifestyle change, so we change the causes of our overweight, instead of attacking the symptom.  For we don't have a weight problem, believe it or not, we have an eating problem. The weight is the result of the problem, it isn't the problem in and of itself--although weight certainly is a problem!


     This movie addresses this directly and indirectly, and we will have a discussion following the movie.

     Here is a trailer:  http://www.imdb.com/title/tt1567233/

     People who RSVP yes will receive my address and phone number the day before the event. If you say "yes", and your plans change, kindly update so someone else may attend.

     If you wind up on the wait list, remember, there are always last-minute changes, and you may well be able to attend.

     Also, if Sundays don't work for you, let me know what day would be better, for future scheduling.  I'm available Mondays and Wednesdays during the week.


     See you then!

Al
results.name: Curb Those Cravings Movie Night--by popular request!

results.description:
Hope everyone's having a great summer!! Sorry for the delay! This month, the selected book is The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks by Rebecca Skloot


http://www.amazon.com/The-Immortal-Life-Henrietta-Lacks/dp/1400052181

#1 NEW YORK TIMES BESTSELLER
Her name was Henrietta Lacks, but scientists know her as HeLa. She was a poor black tobacco farmer whose cells—taken without her knowledge in 1951—became one of the most important tools in medicine, vital for developing the polio vaccine, cloning, gene mapping, and more. Henrietta's cells have been bought and sold by the billions, yet she remains virtually unknown, and her family can't afford health insurance. This phenomenal New York Times bestseller tells a riveting story of the collision between ethics, race, and medicine; of scientific discovery and faith healing; and of a daughter consumed with questions about the mother she never knew.


While it's fairly short notice, only a couple weeks to get this one read, it is a pretty fast moving, easy read so hopefully we'll all be able to get at least mostly through it.  And no matter what, there will be plenty of good food, good wine and even better company. So come with your favorite snack or drink to share, ready to connect with fun friendly neighbors over a great read! 


Oh and just a note in case anyone is allergic, I do have a cat.
results.name: August Book Club Night ~ The Immortal Life of Henrietta Lacks

results.description:
ASK RECEPTION WHERE THE RESERVED TALL TABLES ARE.

Please bring cash and pay as you go!  Please Mix & Mingle, don't get glued to your seats.

You don't have to be a genuine intellectual-- pseudo-intellectuals are also welcome.

All you need is an aloof attitude full of irony or some baffling ideas, or-- dare I say it-- some unanswered  metaphysical question you never figured out that you want answered incognito.

What constitutes success? Money? Love? Power? & what's most important to succeed? Persistence? Cunning? Creativity?

Interestingly, most advice people give each other is about how to succeed (or how to not fail). Gather your rosebuds while ye may; a stitch in time saves nine, waste not want not, knock & ye shall enter, where there's a will there's a way, carpe diem (seize the day), look before you leap, etc.

Here's something from Woody Allen, on "How to Succeed at Anything"--

"The less you can think about yourself, the better. 
It's like being a baseball pitcher; the less you're conscious of your motion the better you pitch.  Just do good work, don't waste time thinking about anything else, ...don't pay attention to the distractions that people send your way, and everything will fall into place." ...actor Will Smith: "Don't chase people. Just do good work and the right people will come to you".

Now here are some expert advice examples from authorities of ancient times: on succeeding--

"Greatness is dealing only with matters of great consequence";
"Most powerful is he who has himself in his own power"
I think these quotes are from Seneca. On failure:

"He who is not master over himself is bound to live in slavery"
(Marcus Aurelius [?])
"The gormandizing that allures the servile crowd is a trap to free men" (Spartans--quoted in Plutarch[?]).   

Above: "Gather ye Rosebuds While ye May," (1909).   

Humor in good taste-- ALLOWED. Intellectual apparel: allowed. Startle the waitstaff with a goatee, Periwig, or monocle. Fold-up sunglasses, fake fold up mustaches, corduroy jackets with elbow patches-- allowed. No Meerschaum tobacco pipes, please. Absinthe is not served.
results.how_to_find_us: Special reserved "tall tables" just behind Reception.
results.name: Intellectual Snob Meetup: How do you Measure Success?

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Monday, August 24
Great Meadows National Wildlife Refuge, Concord
Park in the large parking lot at the end of the main entrance to the refuge, off Monsen Rd., Concord. Walk from the parking lot along the main dike (between the two impoundments). We'll meet at the platform halfway down the dike on the right. If the refuge lowers the water in one of the impoundments, we'll scan the lower pool for shorebirds. We also will watch for herons, egrets, wood ducks, etc. as they settle in for their evening roost. Last year, several of us stayed past dark to hear both Great Horned Owl and Eastern Screech Owls calling from the woods across the lower impoundment. Insect repellent helpful, particularly once the sun sets. 5:30-7:00 PM. Janet Kovner
results.name: Birding Great Meadows Concord evening

results.description:
ear Boston Culture Lovers, 

Let's dance Salsa In the Park! 

Salsa in the Park is a series of free, outdoor Salsa dancing, lessons, music, and performances in the courtyard/playground  park at the Blackstone Community Center in Boston's South End neighborhood.  Two to three dance floors are set-up for each event.

***

FEATURES OF THE EVENT 

• FREE 30-minute lessons for all levels on all floors from 6 pm - 6:30 pm (and again only for beginners at 7:15 pm on one floor)﻿ 

• Social Dance to the best Salsa & Bachata music provided by DJ Hernan and fantastic guests 

• Performances throughout the evening by amazing local and national performers varying in music and dance genres.

http://mmsalsainthepark.weebly.com/about-salsa-in-the-park-sitp.html 

***

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and intend to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group.  

The meeting time for the Meet-up Group is 5:45 pm at 50 West Brookline Street, the entrance to the dance venue.  The plan is to meet and gather at this meeting point and then go into to the park for the 6 pm dance lesson.  

Since this event will be a somewhat crowded and roaming , it will be very difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we  to be able  recognize you from the crowds.  Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone and concentrate on enjoying the event with fellow group members.  

Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event. 

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

***

MORE EVENT DETAILS

BAG CHECK AREA 

If you have items with you, don't worry! We have a Bag Check area where you can safely leave your belongings with one of our MM staff(donations appreciated and encouraged). And if it rains, we'll dance inside at the Blackstone Community Center! 

PARKING: 

On-Street parking available on Shawmut Avenue and Washington Street

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION:

Orange line to Back Bay, exit Dartmouth Street side (it's about a 10 minute walk). Take a left on Dartmouth St and continue walking a few blocks until you cross over Tremont St. where Dartmouth St becomes W. Dedham St. Continue on W Dedham and then take right on Shawmut Ave. and the first left onto W. Brookline St. The center, courtyard park and basketball courts are on your left. 

Silver Line (SL4 or SL5 - Washington St line): Get off at the E Newton St. stop. You will be on Washington St. If you were coming from Dudley and towards Downtown you will continue in the direction the bus is going for one more block, and take a left at W. Brookline; walk down and the basketball courts, courtyard park and center are on your right. If you were coming from Downtown towards Dudley, you will walk back one block, and take a left on W. Brookline as described above. 

Take Bus #1 down Mass Ave. (from Harvard or Central Square). Get off at Washington St, and take a left (heading towards downtown, away from Roxbury). Continue to W. Brookline St., and take a left; walk down and the basketball courts, courtyard park and center are on your right.

results.description:
Come join us at our water training sessions! No prior experience necessary. New paddlers welcome at all times of the season.

Mon & Wed: 6pm - 8pm, meet 5.45pm by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.  
Sat: 11am - 1pm, meet 10.45am by the grassy patch near Barking Crab.

Price: New paddler 2-class pack for $10. All other paddlers paddle unlimited under the $110 annual membership fee. New paddlers who have purchased the $10 intro pack get a $10 deduction from $110 membership!

Outdoor paddling means exposure to the weather! Be prepared to get wet!

Clothing: Wear workout clothes, synthetic fibers that dry quickly are highly recommended. Bring dry clothes to change into afterwards.  
Footwear: Sandals or flip flops recommended. Some people go barefoot. Shoes and socks are not recommended.  
Other: Bring plenty of water and sunscreen.

All paddling equipment is provided (paddles, pfds). Locker provided on-site.

Please sign our e-Waiver before you get on the water

Hope to see you there!

Lily[masked]

 

In the event of inclement weather, announcements will be made through the comments area of each meetup event, also in Twitter, Facebook and email alerts.

Sign up for our weekly emails and email alerts

Twitter: @Boston1Dboat

Facebook: http://bit.ly/Boston1facebook

 

Parking: </a>Parking: <a href="http://www.fortpointpier.com/info.php#DirectionsParkingPortage">Channelside Parking at 284 A Street. Enter at 29-41 Necco Street, off Melcher Street. Weekend $6 flat rate.

Public Transport: Closest MBTA stop is South Station on the Red Line.

results.description:
We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Hi all,
I thought it might be fun to get together and play volleyball with other single people. All ages are welcome but I wanted to make sure people 30 + knew they were extra welcome (I am 49). I have 2 nets. We can have a beginner net and intermediate net if we have enough people. I can do some light coaching.

Weather looks risky all weekend and Monday as well but I wanted to put this in to see how much general interest there is.  If you are interested but this date doesn't work, let me know in the comments section! And let me know what dates and times work best.  I could move this to Sunday PM Aug 23 vs. Mon Aug 24 if that is better...

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

TTYL, JD

results.description:
Hello Cloudsters!

We are very excited and grateful to Foley & Lardner, LLP, for sponsoring and hosting this next meetup.  Their space is spectacular, and so is the food they are planning to serve!

Aaron Tantleff (bio below) will present:

“Cloud Computing SLAs and Legal Issues" Negotiating contracts with cloud service providers, data security, data breaches, and more.”

Erik Levitt (bio below) will present:

"Key Concepts in Selecting Cloud Providers"

Format:

6:00pm - Networking Time

6:30pm - Presentations Begin

*We have an opening for one additional presentation, so please email if you would like to present.

Food will be ‘an awesome array of sandwiches, with a mean spread of cheese and desserts,' from Viga (http://vigaeatery.com/).

Speaker Bios:

Aaron K. Tantleff is a partner and intellectual property lawyer with Foley & Lardner LLP. Mr. Tantleff works closely with clients on privacy, security and information management matters as well as state, federal and international restrictions on the use of information. He has extensive experience advising businesses regarding the drafting and negotiation of privacy and security provisions in a wide range of agreements. Mr. Tantleff has also formulated and drafted privacy, security and data use compliance policies and procedures. He is well acquainted with security breach notification laws, EMR/EHR/PHR matters, HIPAA and other medical privacy laws and social media and blogging policies. Mr. Tantleff has conducted investigations of data security breaches and has identified and proposed best practices in light of those breaches.Mr. Tantleff has worked with companies in a wide range of industries, including financial services, consulting, information technology, communications, consumer markets (retail, wholesale and distribution), life sciences, pharmaceuticals, health care and health services, manufacturing, media, technology, software development, automotive, transportation, energy, chemicals and utilities.

Erik Levitt is the co-Founder and CEO of Open Data Centers, a carrier neutral data center facility located in Piscataway, New Jersey. ODC offers colocation, dedicated server and cloud services to its clients.
A 25 year veteran of the telecommunications industry, Mr. Levitt founded 1stPoint Communications, a nationwide competitive local exchange carrier in 2012 and Endstream Communications, a wholesale voice services provider in 2007. Mr. Levitt founded Core Technology Services, a managed services provider, in 1995, which was acquired by Access Integrated Technologies (NASD:CIDM) in 2004 and was President & COO of AccessIT Managed Services until 2007.
Mr. Levitt has a degree in International Business and Management from the Stern School of Business at New York University and has been a practicing data communications engineer since 1990 and served clients in the financial services sector such as Citigroup, Merrill Lynch, JP Morgan and many others. Prior to 1990 Mr. Levitt was a marketing consultant.

New players VERY welcome:

We will teach you how to play.

The 50 cent charge is totally voluntary and is only to approximately cover the meetup charge, however It is suggested that you buy a drink or something else there, to compensate the hosting establishment.

New people are very welcome and will probably will play their first few hands, about an hour of instruction, with the Meetup organizer and selected players before playing at-large with the rest of the group.

This is SOCIAL CARDS conversation is encouraged, however please be aware of when it is your turn to bid or play a card, we try to keep the fun balanced and considerate of everyone between the two activities.


https://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&tab=wl&outputclassic&dg=brw

1. Route 107 AKA Highland Ave toward Jackson St

<a>2. Turn right onto Jackson St 0.3 mi</a>

3. Turn right onto Jefferson Ave <a>0.1 mi 44 Jefferson Ave Salem, MA 01970</a>

 PUBLIC:

Buses stop at Washington and Derby

Bus numbers 450, 451, 455, 456, 459, 465

From there walk past the Post Office then past Salem House of Pizza on Margin, then past bend in road at Salem Police Station on Margin.

Now going straight ahead you will be on Jefferson, (because Margin St diverts to the right), then past U-Haul at minor bend in road.  

Vinny's is opposite Salem Fibers on Jefferson, about 1/2 mile total.

Vinney's can not be seen from bus stop due to the offset and bends in the roads. But, you should be able to see the Salem House of Pizza, tucked into the corner (of this not very Square?) past the Post Office.

The Salem Train Station is further away, about 3/4 mile, at Washington and Bridge Streets.

Additionally:

Both: The 450 and 456 Buses have stops at ("route 107 AKA Highland Ave" at the Essex, Dalton, Broad, and  Jackson intersection), Just past the Collins Middle School on the hill. You can walk down Jackson street, by the side of the Collins Middle School to Jefferson street, Vinney's will be to the right.  This walk is slightly shorter than the walk from the Washington Street stop about 3/8 mile.

results.description:
Indoor Rock Gym:  Central Rock Gym Watertown Ma (Monday's)

This Meetup is for weekly climbing at the Central Rock Gym in Watertown, MA. This meetup is intended to provide climbing partners for both lead and top rope climbers that sign up for the meetups.

Meet by the cubbies facing the Lead Wall (they will be on the right as you enter). I (Lovey) am usually wearing a teal harness with green & black climbing shoes.  Climb for 1.5 to 3 hrs. Adults of all skill levels and ages welcomed.  

**If you are leading, you should have your own rope. Work it out with your partner as to whose rope you'll be using if only one rope will be used between the two of you. Sometimes lead climbers prefer to lead on their own rope so both lead climbers may bring their own ropes to use. Word of caution: other climbers may help themselves to the second rope when it's not in use.


**If you come late, come find me or ask the CRG staff for help.  They know we climb on Mondays and can help you find the group. 

**There is another meetup group (and perhaps a second) that also climbs Watertown Mondays nights. If you miss the RSVP deadline, would appreciate a courtesy email/call to let me know you'll be joining us so I know to expect you.


**You are required to fill out the rock gym waivers. Go to their website http://www.centralrockgym.com/watertown.php and fill out their Liability Waiver online to save time when you arrive at the gym. 

**It is your responsibility to make sure you have taken the CRG Belay and/or Lead tests. If you have never climbed at CRG, you will be required to take their Belay test given by their staff only. Please make certain to come a bit early to allow for time to take their belay test.

**If you have never belayed before, please make sure to take the "Intro Belay Class". You can sign up for this class (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

**If you are interested in taking their Intro To Leading Climbing class, you can sign up for it at (http://www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown under "Climbing Instruction).

Equipment required: harness, shoes, chalk and belay device. 


Day Passes - $20 (Student/Military: $16)

10-Day Punch card $180 (Student/Military: $144)


Gear Rental:

- $8 Full Package

- $5 Harness

- $5 Shoes

Mountaineering, Skiing – Alpine or Back Country, Rock & Ice Climbing by its very nature is an extremely hazardous activity.

Falling off any part of an climbing route or bouldering challenge or other associated activities, even hiking to a destination may result in injury or death. results.description:
The book for August is The Boston Girl by Anita Diamant.

Description from Amazon.com:  From the New York Times bestselling author of The Red Tent and Day After Night, comes an unforgettable novel about family ties and values, friendship and feminism told through the eyes of a young Jewish woman growing up in Boston in the early twentieth century.

Addie Baum is The Boston Girl, born in 1900 to immigrant parents who were unprepared for and suspicious of America and its effect on their three daughters. Growing up in the North End, then a teeming multicultural neighborhood, Addie’s intelligence and curiosity take her to a world her parents can’t imagine—a world of short skirts, movies, celebrity culture, and new opportunities for women. Addie wants to finish high school and dreams of going to college. She wants a career and to find true love.

Eighty-five-year-old Addie tells the story of her life to her twenty-two-year-old granddaughter, who has asked her “How did you get to be the woman you are today.” She begins in 1915, the year she found her voice and made friends who would help shape the course of her life. From the one-room tenement apartment she shared with her parents and two sisters, to the library group for girls she joins at a neighborhood settlement house, to her first, disastrous love affair, Addie recalls her adventures with compassion for the naïve girl she was and a wicked sense of humor.

Written with the same attention to historical detail and emotional resonance that made Anita Diamant’s previous novels bestsellers, The Boston Girl is a moving portrait of one woman’s complicated life in twentieth century America, and a fascinating look at a generation of women finding their places in a changing world.

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are ladies night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic tables near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the event Host(s) (see RSVP list) from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).

Cast: Zac Efron, Emily Ratajkowski, Wes Bentley

WE ARE YOUR FRIENDS is about what it takes to find your voice. Set in the world of electronic music and Hollywood nightlife, an aspiring 23-year-old DJ named Cole (Efron) spends his days scheming with his childhood friends and his nights working on the one track that will set the world on fire. All of this changes when he meets a charismatic but damaged older DJ named James (Bentley), who takes him under his wing. Things get complicated, however, when Cole starts falling for James' much younger girlfriend, Sophie (Ratajkowski). With Cole's forbidden relationship intensifying and his friendships unraveling, he must choose between love, loyalty, and the future he is destined for.

WE ARE YOUR FRIENDS has been rated R for language throughout, drug use, sexual content and some nudity

NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
Final Week of the program. Learn info about ways to travel and live abroad for little money. The program is FREE and sponsored by the library. I usually bring "MATE" which is Argentina's Friendship Drink" to share. You bring the cookies :)

Here's a bit of background posted in the library's calendar...

TRAVEL
"Have you ever wanted to pack it all up in boxes, put it in storage and take off to experience life in another location? This is your chance to talk with someone that has been enjoying a nomadic lifestyle for the last several years. Patricia has lived in and traveled the USA, South America and Europe. Learn her tips for inexpensive accommodations, alternatives to being on the move, how to pack, handle money and more.

Patricia is a member of Internations and HELPX and various other expat and traveler communities. She is also a seasoned CouchSurfing Ambassador and the moderator of the Buenos Aires Over 35 group.

I am also an environmental artist. I am supposed to do the first 1.5 hours about travel and the second 1.5 about art but I am sure we can mix it up a bit. 


ART HANG OUT
Oh just come and we will find stuff in the surrounding woods to make tiny bit of environmental art or something. Or bring a sketchpad and we will draw and color together and drink mate and eat cookies. I have a cordless drill in the trunk of my car and we can drill holes in corncobs (I used them in the environmental art installation dress below. It was pouring out when I hung it on the tree.)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YWwe0mnXU9g

!!! QUESET HOUSE IS BEHIND THE AMES FREE LIBRARY!!!

The 1920's gardens have been restored by the stone house and it is a fab place to eat cookies and chat. (Remember to bring your own cookies and some for me too.)

results.description:
Update:  This will be the last Nine and Dine for the season, getting dark earlier now.  We will meet at the Horseshoe Grill after playing golf to celebrate our season.   It has been a lot of fun, we have met a lot of new members, had a lot of laughs, too much Tuesday rain and fun golf games.  Thanks to everyone who participated.

Hillview Golf Course Pro Chris Carter has offered us 4 tee times at 5:15 pm starting the first week in May through the end of August.    I will post this weekly during the season and accept 16 members plus a waitlist.    The 9 hole fee is $22 and golf carts are $8, although this is a very walkable course.  If for any reason you need to cancel out, please do so 24 hours ahead of time. This  allows the  waitlist members  time to fill your spot. 


The HIllview Pro shop does  handicaps for members who would like this.You can post your score at HIllview Pro shop or online for $50 for the season.   Hillview offers lessons for those interested as well a  driving range.  I will make plans at a local restaurant for the "19th" hole and update later.

Please check out the website for further information at http://www.hillviewgc.com

UPDATE: .After a meeting of our Board, and in consideration of our ASGA members,  it was decided to  open this event  to official ASGA members initially, then to meetup members.  ASGA members pay $79 a year for membership.  Any non-ASGA members will incur a surcharge of $5 each week, payable before you golf for that day.  Any non-ASGA member  may become a member by going to www.singlesgolf.com and click 'join' thereby avoiding the surcharge.

Any questions, please contact me by clicking on my profile and then the word 'message' in order to send a private email.
results.how_to_find_us: Please arrive 15-30 min before tee off time, pay greens fee, sign in and be prepared to tee off at 5:15
results.name: ASGA Nine and Dine, Last one for the season.

Salesforce is about to unveil something big and game changing!  For the first time ever, we are all invited to join in a special viewing party to witness the unveiling together and hear from top Salesforce executives, product managers and customers exactly what makes the new Salesforce awesome.  Over 100 groups around the world will be tuning in.  This is a can’t miss event!

Join us to learn, network and have fun!  We will have limited edition giveaways, chances to win cool prizes, and exclusive interaction with executives at the LIVE Salesforce event in San Francisco.  


Agenda

5.30 PM - 5.45 PM - Welcome, Meet & Greet

5:45 PM - 6.15 PM - Constant Contact Success Story

6.15 PM - 6.45 PM - OpFocus Success Story 

7:00PM - 7:30PM  - Pre Show with Gillian Madill

7:30PM - 8:30PM  - Keynote with Top Salesforce Executives & Special Guests

8:30PM - 9:00PM - Surprise Entertainment plus Fun & Interactive Activities for Everyone In Person and Online

Class is 75 minutes long and is held in a beautiful old stone cottage that has been converted to a yoga studio.  

Mindful movement is offered Tuesdays by our meditation teacher ,Randy Hicks, who also leads a sitting Meditation Group on Thursday evenings at 5:30 and a Sunrise yoga class at 6:00 am on Wednesday mornings.

Do you want to learn about or improve your sand doubles game?  Transition your indoor skills to the beach?  Improve consistency of your game in the sand?  Join us every Tue!  This is the 2nd season and it is still free!

5:45 to 6:30 – Review beach strategies and work through skill building drills

6:00-7:30 – Play beach/sand doubles on a men's height net 

If you have a good quality beach net, court ropes, or ball, please bring it!  More nets = more hits.

I am looking forward to sharing many of the skills and strategies I have learned from clinics I have taken.  FYI I am not a professional/certified coach and my level is as described above, generally know what to do but don't always execute consistently.

Reminder to bring water, sunglasses, bug spray and a beach chair. I will be wearing a gray November Project t shirt (same as profile pic).

ATTENDEES and RSVPs

The way the system works, you have to register for each week.  You can register about 3 weeks in advance.

We are trying to build a group of people who attend all (or most Wed nights).

The way the coaching is organized, it builds on previous weeks, so it is preferable to have the same/similar group each week. 

In order to encourage that, when confirming the RSVPs, I will give preference to participants who have attended previously.

Again, I am doing this to encourage a regular group of people.  I regret any frustration that this may cause if your RSVP status is changed.

results.description:
Let's hang out close to home and get to know our neighbors or for those who live outside 02121 head into the community to find out, what's good in the neighborhood.

Playhouse in the Park is another longstanding positive community gathering in a safe setting at which much friend renewing and friend making happens.

AJ Smooth will rock Motown sounds


Get there when you can and stay as long as you're able.

Suggest you bring:

1) chair or blanket

2) snacks or supper

3) insect repellent

4) flashlight

5) board games/playing cards

Check out this link for a useful map of the park, http://www.franklinparkcoalition.org/interactive-map/

Here are a few local places from which you can pick up some decent take out or dine in at:

1) Flames (carribean) 469 Blue Hill Ave (617)[masked] two blocks from zoo entrance across from Grove Hall's Mecca mall

2) Stash's (pizza/salads/chicken) 612 Blue Hill Ave (617)[masked] across the street from zoo entrance Public

There is a CVS and Stop and Shop (460 Blue Hill Ave 02121) in the Grove Hall Mecca Mall on Blue Hill Avenue

PUBLIC TRANSPORTATION:
Check out MBTA or Hop Stop to plan your public transportation route.
Take the Orange Line or Commuter Rail to Forest Hills station, then take the number 16 bus to the Franklin Park Zoo.
Take the Orange Line or Commuter Rail to Ruggles station, then take the number 22, 28, 29, 44 or 45 bus to the Franklin Park.
Take the Red line to Andrew station, then take the number 16 bus to the Franklin Park.

DRIVING DIRECTIONS:
Check out Google <a href="http://maps.google.com/maps?hl=en&tab=wl"></a>to plan your driving route

PARKING:


Elma Lewis Playhouse in the Park history

For many park users who grew up around Franklin Park, the park is synonymous with "The Playhouse." For twelve years, from 1966 - 1978, Elma Lewis brought summer performances to Franklin Park and helped bring the park back from neglect and disuse. Today, in response to huge community interest and to draw diverse Boston residents into the park, the Franklin Park Coalition has revived the Playhouse. For the last seven years, the City of Boston's portable ParkARTS stage has been brought to the park for concerts, theatre, and dance performances. This ambitious summer arts series has been possible with the involvement of experienced partners: the National Center of Afro-American Artists, First Night Boston's Summer Beat, and ParkARTS. You can look forward to summer concerts every Tuesday morning and evening throughout July and August. Morning shows target summer camps and youth programs but also bring elder groups to the park. All are invited to bring a picnic lunch and stay for the day. FPC's Summer Youth Crew members help direct groups to the site, show them a picnic spot, and can be available to play games or lead a walk in the woods after the show. Evening concerts are for everyone. Families bring a picnic basket and lawn chairs. Neighbors and friends make it a social evening. Performers are local favorites like Ray Greene, Fulani Haynes, Andre Ward, and Valerie Stephens. Playhouse Revival Elma Lewis was adamant that if the performance area is revitalized in her name, it must follow the artistic vision and standards of the original Playhouse in the Park. Ms. Lewis worked tirelessly to ensure that African-American children and community members receive disciplined, skilled artistic training and exposure to the most talented musicians and performers of the day. To carry on in her footsteps, Playhouse in the Park has been re-established as an exciting summer venue for multi-cultural performances. The first summers included gospel concerts, Commonwealth Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night’s Dream, children’s performances for summer camp groups, and theatre workshops for youth directed by Our Place Theatre in Roxbury. The Playhouse in the Park is a cultural partnership between the Franklin Park Coalition, the National Center of Afro-American Artists, and the Boston Parks & Recreation Department. First Night Boston's Summer Beat produces the summer season, which includes five or more Tuesdays with a morning children's event and an evening show for everyone. The 2009 Playhouse summer season was made possible with generous support from ParkARTS, the Boston Foundation, and an anonymous donor and many individual contributors to the Franklin Park Coalition. An exciting 2010 season with daytime and evening Tuesday performances is planned. Today, a playhouse stage is brought in for performances and set up near the Overlook ruins. The Coalition would like to return the Playhouse stage to the scenic ruins Miss Lewis used. Summer arts programming, combined with masonry and landscape restoration, will revive this long-neglected area of the park. Elma Lewis was a cultural icon in Boston's black community until her death in January 2004. She was the founder and director of The Elma Lewis School for Fine and Performing Arts in the 1950s, where thousands of African American children and adults studied until it closed in the 1980s. Miss Lewis, who helped start the Franklin Park Coalition, sought to make the park a community gathering place after years of neglect. Miss Lewis and a group of students cleaned up the rat-infested, garbage-strewn area where Olmsted's Overlook Shelter had burned. They built the Playhouse stage amidst the stone ruins and set up chairs. Thus began a summer concert series that took place every night from July 4th to Labor Day for twelve years. Local performers and national stars graced the Playhouse stage, offering drama, dance, music and poetry, all of the high caliber that Miss Lewis demanded. From Duke Ellington's 4th of July concerts to Olatunji and his African drums closing the season on Labor Day, from Billy Taylor and Odetta to the Boston Ballet, people in Boston were exposed to premier arts.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

We will have a private room! Just let the hosts know you're there for UXHH.


No agenda, no speaker, and no pressure. Come and socialize with like-minded UX folk in Boston.

--

Sponsored by Connective DX

Connective DX is a digital experience (DX) agency that helps organizations embrace the power of digital, align around the customer, and take control of their future.

The company, founded in 1997, serves organizations globally from its offices in Portland, OR and Boston’s Innovation District. Clients include BMC Software, Oregon Health & Science University, Columbia Sportswear, Banner Bank, and KinderCare. The agency also organizes the annual Delight Conference, established in 2011 to gather and inspire leaders focused on creating experiences people love.

Are you passionate about customer-centric design? Connective DX is looking for a User Experience Designer to join their XD team in Boston! Contact <a>Bryan Maleszyk</a>, Director of User Experience if you’re interested in applying.

-- All UX Happy Hour Boston attendees are required to adhere to our Code of Conduct.


UX Happy Hour Boston is organized by DockYard

DockYard is a cross-platform interface design and development company based in Boston, MA. We’re hired to solve unique challenges with design, development, and project management for clients of all sizes making impact in both public and private sectors. Yes, your organizer did write this.

About the event: 

Data science is rapidly growing, so are the complexities, tools and techniques. To help data scientists stay ahead they need to have access to better networks. "Data Scientist Networking Gala" is a first step towards building  useful networks, that we could all leverage for helping us grow.

Time for us all to take a deep breath, pause for a moment and meet the fellow data scientists. The evening will be packed with networking, raffles and fun.

Date & Time: August 25, 2015. 6:00pm-9:00pm

Venue: District Hall - 75 Northern Ave, Boston, MA

7:00pm - 9:00pm : Networking session, Open-Mic & refreshments

Registration: Register here. (Required)

Additional Information: Visit Gala Page.

Our Gala Host:

Pointillist is the first marketing analytic software product designed to reveal how customer experiences drive business outcomes. Our solution enables you to understand how all of your marketing campaigns and loyalty programs - across channels and over time - influence customer behavior and key results. As part of a corporate-backed technology accelerator located in Boston’s Seaport district, our team has a proven track record at both successful start-ups and Fortune 500 leaders alike.  If you’re curious, smart, and kind of quirky, you’re probably a good fit.  Let’s talk about how you can help us bring a new perspective to the market with Pointillist. "Analytics for the 99%" is a line that we hold very close to our core belief. But it's always easier said than done. So, we put together Analytics Awareness Week to facilitate dialog, awareness and networking within our rapidly growing data community. Such interaction between data science professionals and businesses will surface several opportunities that lies in the data science community.

Fred (ZHOU Hanlin) and Justin Kwan host these friendly meetups (in Kresge 201).  
Enter as you have long done; then walk UP the open stairway near the security guard's desk.

* Mandarin speakers want to practice English (and reduce their Chinese accents)?
* English speakers want to learn Mandarin?
* Nerdy Chinese folks want to bring friends and have a fun, FREE "outing" in Boston just talking with nerdy strangers in English or Mandarin?

This week, our guest speaker Brendon, professional English teacher, will have a very interesting presentation in the meetup. The Topic is "Mandarin vs. English:  A comparison of sounds to promote cross-linguistic phonological awareness"

Do you have trouble pronouncing certain sounds in English or Chinese? Brendon will tell us the reasons why we have a trouble and share some ideas in the meetup.  

He will also explain the art of beatboxing as a technique to help Mandarin speakers pronounce English sounds, since he has used beatboxing to teach pronunciation in his ESL class of native Chinese speakers.

Spend some time on your project by bringing it along to our weekly project night, an evening designed around you and what you're working on.

This weekly event is about finding time to tinker, being creative, and meeting other members of the community.  You'll get the chance to see what others are working on, share your projects, and to get inspiration and feedback from fellow tinkerers.

On any given Tuesday night you have people working on electronics, knitting, writing code, wood-working, or just their plans for world domination. Beer is also consumed.

We’ll provide: space to work, basic tools, power, a room full of like minded people.

You’ll provide: your project, ideas and beer. A laptop would probably be useful too.

Sometimes we work on group projects together, which are usually set up as separate meetup events. Keep an eye on our events page to see what we’re working on next.

results.description:
They were America's longest lasting dynasty, the closest thing to a royal family our nation has ever known. The Adamses played a leading role in America's affairs for nearly two centuries -- from John, the self-taught lawyer who rose to the highest office in the government he helped to create; to John Quincy, the child prodigy who followed his father to the White House and fought slavery in Congress; to Charles Francis, the Civil War diplomat; to Henry, the brilliant scholar and journalist. Indeed, the history of the Adams family can be read as the history of America itself. For when the Adamses "looked at their past, they saw the nation's," writes author Richard Brookhiser. "When they looked at the nation's past, they saw themselves."

America's First Dynasty charts the family's travels through American history along with an impressive cast of characters, among them George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Ulysses S. Grant, and Theodore Roosevelt. Brookhiser also details the darker side of the Adams experience, from the specters of alcoholism and suicide to the crushing burden of performance passed on from father to son. Yet by putting a human face on this legendary family, Brookhiser succeeds in creating an impassioned, heroic family portrait that the American public is not likely to forget.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the front of the cafe near the windows.
results.name: America's First Dynasty: The Adamses, 1735-1918 by Richard Brookhiser

We start off chatting about our work, including setting goals for ourselves (which is entirely optional but super helpful!), and then we write. That's what it's all about. As simple as the idea is, it's amazing how much more you can get done simply by being in the presence of other writers at work. The baked goods don't hurt, either.


There is power for laptops, and some of us use pen and paper. Your choice! Bonus: there's no Internet access, so you can omit a huge distraction without even trying. And, although we are not a discussion group, there are many areas where people can go if they want to talk without being disruptive.

Please click here for detailed directions! The school can be a bit of a maze and I don't want anybody getting lost.

HOW TO GET THERE

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. results.description:
Have you always wanted to run a little stronger, a little faster, and have some motivated people around to help push you along? Well now you can have all of those things at the best Track workout ever.

Interest peaked? Read on for more details including the weekly workout.

Meet at the Harvard Track as usual. See what the workout will be below.


View Larger Map

The workout is a simple speed workout designed to add some variety to your run.

The rest of this details the workout and highlights a few things I think are important to remember. Skip it if you would rather just wing it and meet us at the track. We'll fill you in there.

If you have never run on a track before, don't worry if none of this makes sense right now. As much as I will try to prep you, it usually just takes a few laps around the track for all of this to sink in.

The Workout

The workouts vary on a weekly basis and are usually interval based. We sometimes do workouts that are fun and different. Come see what this weeks workout is!

What does that mean?

1. The distances (200, 400, 800, etc.) are the distances we run on the track. Each lap around the track is 400 meters.

2. Each lap is supposed to be run at a certain speed, based on your 5k pace. Don't know what your 5k pace is? Read my instructions below to calculate your 5k pace.

*3. The recovery interval (RI), which is indicated in parentheses, may be a specified timed interval or a distance that you walk/jog.

Things to remember

Track workouts are supposed to be FUN! Don't be intimidated or dread a track workout. This is supposed to be a fun supplement to your other "normal" runs. With all of us out there encouraging each other it should be a blast.

Bring a running stopwatch/wristwatch if you have one! Using the start/lap/stop function will help you pace yourself on each lap.

Don't push it! If something hurts or starts to feel tight, don't risk an injury because you ran too hard on your first track workout of the summer. We have plenty of time to ease in...

Bring water for the end!!!

5k pace instructions

Decide how fast you would like to run a 5k. Choose a time that is reasonable yet challenging. Convert that time to seconds, and divide the seconds by 12.5 (the number of 400 meter laps it takes to run 5k). That is your 5k pace.

As an example, I might decide a reasonable yet challenging goal time for a 5k is 24 minutes.

24 minutes x 60 seconds per minute = 1440 seconds

1440 seconds divided by 12.5 laps in a 5k ~= 115 seconds / lap

This means that I will run the workout according to a pace of 115 seconds / lap.

I will also have pacing charts available at the track, so don't fret.

Blog

By Car: If you are driving, parking at the restaurant is ample and free.

From inside the city:  Take Rt 9 outbound, and take a left onto Calumet after Brigham & Women's.

results.description:
Experience being so present with the people you are speaking to that you find yourself speaking with ease -- and impact.  

Learn how to stand in front of any group of people, and feel absolutely confident and at ease.

If you would like to express yourself with greater clarity and to connect more deeply with those whom you address, a Speaking Circle® will guide you toward effortless authenticity.

Speaking Circles help:
* Business professionals who want to become more effective, authentic and powerful.
* People who want to be more fully present, confident and authentic.
* People who suffer from stage fright or "being shy".

Hope to see you soon,

Dexter Nardella

Our Speaking Circle supports you to learn how to express yourself -- in your own time and in your own unique way -- without fear and without discomfort. 

Some call this authentic expression, “speaking from the heart,” “the authentic self” or “your real voice.”   Whatever you call it, you will know when you are there and you will be able to tell when someone else is there. 

Click to read FAQs about a Speaking Circle. http://www.speakingcirclesinternational.com/Articles/Principles/FAQ.html#.VKx9y0c76rU

See and hear participants talk about their experience in SPEAKING CIRCLES:


http://youtu.be/Wi82ZIgioh0

Leader:

Dexter Nardella is a certified Speaking Circle® facilitator trained by Lee Glickstein, the originator of Speaking Circles. <a></a>He first experienced Speaking Circles in 2004 when he was looking for a way to feel at ease speaking to the audiences he addressed as a chiropractor. 

During my many years as a chiropractor, I often explained to patients that within each one of us there lies a wise 'healing system' capable of fighting off disease, combating infection and bringing us greater energy, vitality and well-being.  Now, the simple guidelines of a Speaking Circle invite participants to discover a direct extension of that wisdom. The experience of witnessing participants speaking from that quality of presence is nothing short of amazing.

My calling is to help people be present to who they really are and to speak from that presence.  It would be my privilege to support you on your journey. Join us in speaking from the heart and relax into the wonder of being yourself.
results.name: SpeakingCircles: Practicing Authentic Presence

results.description:
Contact me [Jose (click the link, then click "Message")] for the address.

General board gaming. We have a good library of widely played board games, and people normally bring many more of them. We regularly run three to five tables of board games - this provides enough variety.  It is normal for people to get two or three games a session.  The game night format was inspired by Unity Games and the event is very casual and structureless.  If you have gone to one of the meetup's quarterly events you will know.

Q & A:

Q.  What types of games are played?
A.  Any type of board game.  Browse through the most popular games at http://boardgamegeek.com/ and that should give you an idea.

Q.  Until when do you play games?  Can I arrive later than 7pm?
A.  Until the last game of the evening ends, usually past midnight.  Yes, you can arrive later than 7pm, but you may have to wait for a new game to start if you do.

Q.  Should I bring something?  
A.  If you want, bring a game you feel comfortable teaching. There will be pizza and sodas served. Feel free to bring snacks or beverages to share or chip in $5 to $10 for the pizza/sodas in the pizza cup. 

Q.  I really want to play XYZ game, can we schedule it?
A.  Some people ask for interest in a particular game on the event comments below.  This may be the way to make sure you get to play the game you want. 

Q.  Where do I park?
A.  The driveway is the obvious spot, but eventually it will fill up on most of these game nights.  Some people do park on the street.  The soccer field parking across the street is a safe option and is the suggestion the town police gave me when I asked about overflow parking.
results.how_to_find_us: The house is just across from a soccer field.  If the driveway starts to fill up, the soccer field parking lot is a good option.

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
